Even better.....you can have the food delivered through one of the popular food delivery services and enjoy them at home (or work).
bento.author: Dean J.
bento.review: One of my top go-to places for fresh and delicious Japanese food. We really like their Sushi Sampler Bento Box with inventive and tasty dishes that are a terrific value for the price. Even better.....you can have the food delivered through one of the popular food delivery services and enjoy them at home (or work).

excerpts: I opted for one of their bento box options - 2 sides and 1 main, with sesame salad, green bean salad and upgraded to a tuna roll for the whopping price tag of $15.
bento.author: Jessica M.
bento.review:
Humph.

I really had high hopes for Delica after reading some fellow Yelper's reviews, but I'm left feeling underwhelmed. I opted for one of their bento box options - 2 sides and 1 main, with sesame salad, green bean salad and upgraded to a tuna roll for the whopping price tag of $15.

Perhaps it's the price tag that's leaving a sore taste in my mouth? While I enjoyed the salads, they weren't over the top and the tuna roll was really just okay and not worth the $3 upcharge.

I was looking for fresh and quick and Delica certainly delivered on that account, but I'm torn as to whether or not I return...

excerpts: I've ordered the Assorted Sushi Bento via Caviar and I must emphasize that the to-go packaging was so adorable!
The bento was $14, but wasn't nearly as filling!
I have yet to also try the other bento options, so will be back in the near future.
bento.author: Jenny H.
bento.review:
Pretty cool sushi rolls and salads! I've ordered the Assorted Sushi Bento via Caviar and I must emphasize that the to-go packaging was so adorable! I've heard great things about the curry, so it's definitely on my hit list.

Although I appreciate the creativity, I wish they provided larger portions. The bento was $14, but wasn't nearly as filling! I could've finished another box because it was so delicious.

I have yet to also try the other bento options, so will be back in the near future. :)

excerpts: You can order prepared, prepackaged items-dumplings croquettes sushi and bento to go, or order off the menu.
Menu items can be to go or dine in, but there is no waiter service.
They have the delicatessen style of ordering from counter and call out system.
In house orders get the metal stand with  number, everybody else gets a hand off over the counter.
The architecture is very contemporary lots stainless steel and wood with the lots subtle natural and discreet artificial lighting.
The overall effect is very well done, the dining has a snug cozy feel, while keeping the counter area crisp and bright.
The seating is varuios (Edit to self: Dude.
Seriously.
VARIOUS.
Why can't you spell that word correctly?)
dark wood table/chair combos
but I can't tell you too much about that
as when it comes to the ferry building, I'm all about the grab and go.
The best sushi is at the sushi counter slightly inside, as the counter options tend to be slightly more basic and standardized.
Get one of the super awesome salads, or even the bento choices-those change from day to day and are more then sufficient for a very satisfying lunch.
bento.author: Steven W.
bento.review:
This is a Japanese style restaurant tucked away in the ferry building.

Parking? Ha, Ha, no. There is a loading area behind the building-that isn't marked out in any way, by where sinbad's used to be, kinda sorta by the Gandhi statue/outdoor dining section, and the never really available SF street parking. Like prettty much everything else in downtown SF you'll be best served by finding a way to come here that does not involve driving.

This is a unexpectedly large Japanese delicatessen with a world cuisine menu. You can order prepared, prepackaged items-dumplings croquettes sushi and bento to go, or order off the menu. Menu items can be to go or dine in, but there is no waiter service. They have the delicatessen style of ordering from counter and call out system. In house orders get the metal stand with  number, everybody else gets a hand off over the counter. The architecture is very contemporary lots stainless steel and wood with the lots subtle natural and discreet artificial lighting. The overall effect is very well done, the dining has a snug cozy feel, while keeping the counter area crisp and bright. The seating is varuios (Edit to self: Dude. Seriously.VARIOUS. Why can't you spell that word correctly?) dark wood table/chair combos but I can't tell you too much about that as when it comes to the ferry building, I'm all about the grab and go. The best sushi is at the sushi counter slightly inside, as the counter options tend to be slightly more basic and standardized. Tasty and awesome no matter what you chose,

The food here is excellent. It's hard to go wrong with any item. I am a huge fan of the croquettes-whether they are veg or meat. They are huge-about the size of my fist,and fried to crispy perfection. Want something healthy? Get one of the super awesome salads, or even the bento choices-those change from day to day and are more then sufficient for a very satisfying lunch. 

Pricing? Well a croquette will run you 7 bucks or so, and if you get something to drink you are looking at ten dollars at a minimum. Salad/soup/lunch combo thingys will typically be around 15 dollars and there does not appear to be a top end limit at the sushi counter. It's entirely possible to get a hundred dollar tab at the sushi sit in counter, but for those who don't roll that big fifteen bucks will get you the best lunch you'll have all week, I've focused on the most common items, but bear in mind that the menu here is quite extensive and customizable. There are dozens of items that I'm not so familiar with, and will possible not get to as it's hard for me to get past the croquettes. Did I mention how good they are? 

I consider this a must do in the ferry building.

excerpts: I ordered the bento box for $12.25 with the Hijiki and Soybean Salad in it
and it was about the same size.
How is that even possible?
They either gave me the wrong box because there's no way that was
1/2 lb
or it's a scam.
that as a part of the bento.
It was SOOOO NOT WORTH THE MONEY.
It tasted pretty good according to a coworker
but I was too mad about the size to care.
Anyway, just order the bento and not the salad themselves.
bento.author: Kimberly W.
bento.review:
I'm torn because I really wanted to like Delica. I will definitely come back here again and try it in person. I ordered delivery from Caviar and the food was pretty good.

However, I was very surprised when my $8 Hijiki and Soybean Salad came in this tiny little box. I ordered the bento box for $12.25 with the Hijiki and Soybean Salad in it and it was about the same size. How is that even possible? They either gave me the wrong box because there's no way that was 1/2 lb or it's a scam. Will post pictures later.

Yelpers, DO NOT order Hijiki and Soybean Salad as an entree $8, just order that as a part of the bento. It was SOOOO NOT WORTH THE MONEY. It tasted pretty good according to a coworker but I was too mad about the size to care. It SAID 1/2 lb salad.

I didn't have to pay a dime for it myself and I though it was a waste of money.

I had the beef curry which I thought was pretty well made, the meat was very soft and the sauce was good. The curry and rice came in the portions I thought was going to come in, but the salad was just super disappointing. 

The $5 shrimp each was a bit expensive but it was pretty tasty. The tonkatsu was actually better than I thought with a little bit of the sauce they put on it. The chicken dumpling looked very tasty and flavorful (coworkers ate it all :P). They were price per piece so they felt a bit on the pricier side but if you're into that, this is for you.

I hope to be able to review this place again and up the rating because I think this restaurant can do better. The beef curry was reasonably priced in my opinion. I really enjoyed my meal but I am very mad about the salad (because I felt cheated). Anyway, just order the bento and not the salad themselves.

excerpts: The bento boxes look good.
Will try it sometime.
Overall worth the money!
bento.author: Steffi C.
bento.review:
I have become quite fond of this place. A great spot for lunch.
Be sure to get in before 12. The line can get long but they do move quickly.
I often get the main + soup + salad combo. The chicken dumplings are great. I also like the Kakiage tempura. 
Carrot and ginger soup is my favorite among the soups.
Also try the Spicy Burdock and Lotus Roots Salad .
The bento boxes look good. Will try it sometime.
Overall worth the money!

excerpts: sushi bento (3.5/5): a great variety
but nothing really stood out.
Considering the quality & the amount of food they gave you, we think $14.75 for the bento is at the more expensive side.
--Sweet & Spicy chicken (2/5): first of all, $1.85 for only a really really small piece of chicken, ugh...
Also, the chicken was not spicy at all.
It was really sweet.

Definitely will not order again.
--Tofu & Chicken Patty with Hijiki (4.5/5): probably our favorite dish among the ones we ordered.
The sauce was not overly sweet and the patty was really good.
If we order again from Delica, this dish will definitely be a must-order one.
bento.author: Clare L.
bento.review:
It was not as impressive as I expected. The food display was cute but the taste was pretty meh.

My friends and I ordered through Caviar and here are our thoughts on each dish we ordered:
--Ginger Beef Bowl (3/5): this dish was REALLY SWEET. We did not expect this much sweetness at all. Also, it was really oily. Near the bottom of the rice, you can see oil flowing around. We were really excited about this dish until we had our first bite. Really Disappointing.
--Assorted sushi bento (3.5/5): a great variety but nothing really stood out. Considering the quality & the amount of food they gave you, we think $14.75 for the bento is at the more expensive side.
--Sweet & Spicy chicken (2/5): first of all, $1.85 for only a really really small piece of chicken, ugh... Also, the chicken was not spicy at all. It was really sweet. Definitely will not order again.
--Tofu & Chicken Patty with Hijiki (4.5/5): probably our favorite dish among the ones we ordered. The sauce was not overly sweet and the patty was really good. If we order again from Delica, this dish will definitely be a must-order one.

excerpts: 4 item Bento --
bento.author: Rodney H.
bento.review:
Yeah, it's been 6 years since my last review for Delica, and with this update, it still a solid 5 stars for me!  I just love coming here!

First and foremost that I should mention, I just had their Beef Curry for the first time and it's probably one of the better Japanese Curries I've had in the city.  I got the regular sized curry and it was a pretty hearty bowl with a good amount of tender beef cubes and potatoes.  And from their hot food section, their crab croquettes are still the thing the get!
Regular Beef Curry w/ Crab Croquette -- http://bit.ly/1jnb8VE

Their salads are still some of the tastiest ones you can have in the Ferry Building.  I still recommend getting the 2 salads and rice combo with their Burdock Root Salad and Lotus Salad.

Their bentos have the perfect balance of veggies, carbs, and proteins.  They're always something worth stopping by for lunch.
4 item Bento -- http://bit.ly/1OAPMkA

Other than their prices being higher than most Japanese markets, simply because it's in the Ferry Building, I really can't see any other flaws with Delica.  Their food is totally fresh and delicious!

excerpts: Ordered a bento box for $15, which came with 9 different types of food, which included 4 different sushi rolls, 4 salads, and a meatball looking thing in the middle.
bento.author: Viet N.
bento.review:
LOL at Yelp for thinking I actually like this place enough to come back repeatedly...

Delica is an ideal Japanese grab-n-go place, offering plenty of ready-to-go bentos. You also have the option of ordering various sides along with rice and soup, with the sides ranging from potato croquette to teriyaki chicken to tofu agedashi, and even tempura.

However, seeing as how it's located at the Ferry Building, all items are more expensive than the usual average downtown SF lunch fare, and to be honest, the food I had wasn't too impressive. 

Ordered a bento box for $15, which came with 9 different types of food, which included 4 different sushi rolls, 4 salads, and a meatball looking thing in the middle. All the items were just satisfactory in taste to me, with nothing standing out other than the roll with the purple rice (only because it was purple). 

Maybe I'll come back after a little while, but there are plenty of other options for quick Japanese food around.

excerpts: I must say the Assorted Sushi Bento is so cute!
I've been dying to try, there are preset 9 items that can be sushi, salads or small dishes.
I love the idea of just trying a bit of everything.
Everything was delicious and presentation was on
bento.author: Natalie L.
bento.review:
I must say the Assorted Sushi Bento is so cute! I've been dying to try, there are preset 9 items that can be sushi, salads or small dishes. I love the idea of just trying a bit of everything. Everything was delicious and presentation was on it's A game for sure.

I would definitely come back next time to try their sushi rolls and curry!

OH CASH ONLY. Had to walk to the ATM and get cash :D

excerpts: I only tried their pre made 9-item bento as it looked so good, but didn't like it at all.
One of rolls smelled badly fishy, green beans were so old and thick that were basically unchewable.
Only the meatball in the middle was okay, but still.. cold and hard..
Wanted to go to that place for a long time and was so disappointed.
And that box plus a bottle of water were 20$, didn't worth even half of that.
If you decide to give this place a try, get something from made-to-order menu.
bento.author: Lena G.
bento.review: I only tried their pre made 9-item bento as it looked so good, but didn't like it at all. One of rolls smelled badly fishy, green beans were so old and thick that were basically unchewable. Only the meatball in the middle was okay, but still.. cold and hard.. Wanted to go to that place for a long time and was so disappointed. And that box plus a bottle of water were 20$, didn't worth even half of that. If you decide to give this place a try, get something from made-to-order menu.

excerpts: You can also get the potato salad and other prepared bento boxes on a side line, which is usually much shorter.
bento.author: Veasna H.
bento.review:
Came here for lunch around 12:30 on a Tuesday and suprisingly there was no line.  May have just missed the rush cause the line is usually out the door for their hot food. I took this opportunity to try their hot bar and got the Beef Curry over rice with a Tonkatsu (sold seperately).  The food here is delicious and well made. The curry was really good and although not top tier, holds its own with some of the other establishments in the city. The Tonkatsu was pretty good, but on the small side, but for under $2, it was a good side to add on,

One of my favorite things here is their Wasabi Potato salad.  It taste refreshing on a warm SF day as a potato salad should, but there is that kick of Wasabi that not only makes it more refreshing, but pretty cleanses the palate effectively.

You can also get the potato salad and other prepared bento boxes on a side line, which is usually much shorter.  These boxes are prepped everyday and are pretty good in quality if you just want to grab something really quick.

A tad on the pricey side, but on par with everything else in the Ferry Building price wise.

excerpts: Here's a local's tip: get the bento box for a cheaper lunch option!
bento.author: Janice C.
bento.review:
Welcome 2015 with a new and healthy you.

Delica makes it easy to eat healthy going by way of organic, gourmet Japanese-California fusion style cuisine. What does this mean to you? a bit pricey for quality food that's really good for your body. Here's a local's tip: get the bento box for a cheaper lunch option!

The eggplant salad was so delicious! I wished she gave me a bigger serving though. I love the comforting warmth of their carrot-ginger soup, packed with beta-carotene which is essential for sharp eyesight and free radical repair. Ginger is a known aphrodisiac, so no other explanation needed ;-) 

Protein is necessary for building muscle and helps delay hunger pangs longer than simple carbs. The tofu-chicken patty is filling and tasty.  Supplement it with croquettes if you're looking for a fried treat. 

Don't be intimidated by the long lines, the staff are trained well in handling a busy lunch crowd. If it's a gorgeous day, sit outside and get some Vitamin D. How about that? All the essential nutrients you need with gorgeous bay views to boot? 

Cheers to a healthy you!

excerpts: I got the 4-item bento for lunch, which included 2 small salads (one with  hijiki, another that was advertised as burdock--I couldn't tell TBH), 3 pieces of saucy breaded chicken, and rice; as well as a shrimp and crab roll.
The bento was $13 and the roll $11.25.
I was more ambivalent about the bento.
The chicken's breading was kind of soggy, which was unpleasant, and the chicken itself wasn't juicy or tender, though not excessively dry either.
I didn't like the salad with hijiki, while the burdock salad was really strange both in texture and taste.
Not the types of salads I'd order independently.
bento.author: Elle E.
bento.review:
I got the 4-item bento for lunch, which included 2 small salads (one with  hijiki, another that was advertised as burdock--I couldn't tell TBH), 3 pieces of saucy breaded chicken, and rice; as well as a shrimp and crab roll. The bento was $13 and the roll $11.25. 

If you want sushi, I highly recommend the shrimp and crab roll. The fillings are real and tasty, the natural sweetness of the shrimp really shines. 

I was more ambivalent about the bento. The chicken's breading was kind of soggy, which was unpleasant, and the chicken itself wasn't juicy or tender, though not excessively dry either. I didn't like the salad with hijiki, while the burdock salad was really strange both in texture and taste. Not the types of salads I'd order independently.

excerpts: There's sushi, bento boxes displayed or items in glass casing that you can choose from.
The staff is super efficient.
They're take your order, have you walk through the stanchions and pay at the end of the line.
The staff wasn't too personable, but they also weren't rude, so I was completely fine with this situation.
bento.author: Rockne H.
bento.review:
My favorite time of the day, Lunchtime! I'm especially excited nowadays because I know San Francisco has a lot of food options to choose from. Not only that, the food is awesome! Today, we decided to visit the famous Ferry business for lunch. Strolling through this place, we came across an Asian joint and you know I'm always down for Asian food, so this was a no brainer!

When you walk into this joint, you're greeted with so many options! There's sushi, bento boxes displayed or items in glass casing that you can choose from. The staff is super efficient. They're take your order, have you walk through the stanchions and pay at the end of the line. The staff wasn't too personable, but they also weren't rude, so I was completely fine with this situation. Also, it was a super busy joint so a quick run through is needed to prevent holding up the line. 

For lunch, I just decided to get everything ala carte. Rice on a plate and then the following: 

-Crab Croquette for $4.00 each. Dungeness crabmeat blended with a creamy bechamel sauce, lightly breaded and fried. The dipping sauce was a dill tartar sauce. So delicious. The croquette was super creamy but didn't ooze out. the breading was super light and crispy. I also loved the flavor the dil tartar sauce brought. So awesome.

-Sweet and Spicy Chicken for $1.50 each. This was great! The chicken was marinated with sake, soy and ginger and then tossed in a sweet and spicy chili sauce. It was so flavorful! The chicken was juicy and not too spicy. 

-Pork Tonkatsu for $1.50 each. Breaded pork with panko and deep fried. Drizzled with homemade tonkatsu sauce. I loved the texture and flavor, however the tonkatsu was cold. I think that's the point of this place but I didn't really like the temperature of the meat. 

All in all, a fantastic place to visit for lunch. It's centrally located and the prices are reasonable. I'm definitely returning to this place in the future and if you're in the area, you should definitely check them out!!

excerpts:
love this little japanese joint - get a pre-made bento box or pick from the counter like at whole foods. 

if you're feeling like you want to splurge
- options: bento boxes, don buri, onigiri, rolls, salads (rotating but hijiki, mushroom, etc), soups (rotating but miso, carrot ginger), etc.
bento.author: Kristie C.
bento.review:
love this little japanese joint - get a pre-made bento box or pick from the counter like at whole foods. 

$9.79 including tax: main + side + rice

// -- the food -- \\ 
- quality, tasty food that's affordable and allows you to mix-and-match what items you want. lots of healthy options, but also lots of fried options if you're feeling like you want to splurge
- options: bento boxes, don buri, onigiri, rolls, salads (rotating but hijiki, mushroom, etc), soups (rotating but miso, carrot ginger), etc.

// -- my food -- \\ 
- tofu/chicken patty: very delicious and flavorful, loved that they added hijiki inside for a different texture / taste
- sesame salad: hefty portions depending when you come. marinated and not drenched in that creamy white sauce that some places do. healthy + highly recommended
- rice: even the rice texture was great

will definitely have to come back

excerpts: cooked Japanese-style bento box-ish.
you pick combos of soup, salads and a main.
most of the mains are fried (potato croquettes, crab, etc.) but are tasty.
the salads are the best choices.
soups are decent too.
there aren't a lot of great value places to eat in the Ferry Building so for $15 or so, this isn't too bad.
staff is weirdly unfriendly every time I've been there (6+ times).
I wouldn't make a special trip to eat here, but if you're in the Ferry Building looking for something fresh and reasonably healthy, this is a okay.
bento.author: Bob U.
bento.review: pretty good for a Ferry Building grab n go. cooked Japanese-style bento box-ish. you pick combos of soup, salads and a main. most of the mains are fried (potato croquettes, crab, etc.) but are tasty. the salads are the best choices. soups are decent too. there aren't a lot of great value places to eat in the Ferry Building so for $15 or so, this isn't too bad. staff is weirdly unfriendly every time I've been there (6+ times). I wouldn't make a special trip to eat here, but if you're in the Ferry Building looking for something fresh and reasonably healthy, this is a okay.

excerpts: Came here once and ordered a bento box here.
bento.author: Jerianne G.
bento.review:
Ahhh.. This place is alright. Not really "DAMN I LOVE IT" but it also isn't "UGH THIS IS GROSS" either.

Located within the Ferry Building in the Embarcadero, you can find Japanese food being served here if you're in the mood for some sushi.

Came here once and ordered a bento box here. I like how unique the box looks, especially since this place works fast (since it gets busy here during the day). 

My box consisted of potato croquette, rice, taro salad, and something with greenbeans. Overall I would say that it was average at best. Not the most amazing thing ever, but not the worse.

There's a lot of seats outside, so sit there and take in the ocean on a sunny day!

Downside is that this place is a money-sucker. Upside is that it's near even more eateries lol.

excerpts: Bento boxes on the table & in the fridge display in the front if you want the pre-selected options and if you want to skip the line.
Pricey?
It seems like it at first since the bento looks small, but I was surprisingly really full from the 5-item vegetarian bento ($10.25)
Everything tastes gourmet and is definitely not something you can re-create easily at home, so
Stick to the bento boxes and lunch sets for the best value.
($5.25 for one-two servings of wasabi mashed potatoes.
Good but NOT WORTH IT
This could also get boring fast though so the portion size in the bento was perfect.
bento.author: Emily C.
bento.review:
3.5 STARS

Fancy Japanese fast-food type deli counter. Bento boxes on the table & in the fridge display in the front if you want the pre-selected options and if you want to skip the line.
Pricey? It seems like it at first since the bento looks small, but I was surprisingly really full from the 5-item vegetarian bento ($10.25) Everything tastes gourmet and is definitely not something you can re-create easily at home, so  it is worth the price tag.

The only thing that knocks down the 1 stars for me is the the wait and checkout process. It's seemingly designed to be fast, however, you end up in the line to pay regardless. I came here at 12 on the dot and after picking up my item, still had to wait about ~7 minutes to pay which doesn't SEEM like that long, but there was only 5-6 people in front of me.. there's only one cashier and people can still order food when they're almost by the register. NOT EFFICIENT...
WHY DOES THE LINE GO SO SLOWWWWWWWW..................

Maybe it's not that bad during non-Farmer's-Market days - I've only been here on Thursdays, so I wouldn't know.

I was a noob the first time and got a few items a la carte. DON'T DO IT. Stick to the bento boxes and lunch sets for the best value. ($5.25 for one-two servings of wasabi mashed potatoes. Good but NOT WORTH IT @_@)

Wasabi mash: Light wasabi flavor but enough to get you going. A bit chunky just asI  like it, peas give a good sweetness to it and the slight bit of romaine lettuce gives it a good texture contrast. I personally wish it was a tad more savory/creamy though.

Hijiki (seaweed) & soybean salad: I personally didn't like it.. it's a little too 'healthy' feeling for me but I'm sure it's REALLY good for you.. Stick to small portions of this. This would probably be better if was mixed with kale or something. The sea-flavor was too intense for me and the texture got boring fast. Felt like my breath stank afterwards..

Burdock salad: still don't really know what this is but this was surprisingly good and healthy! Very light, fresh, and crunchy salad. This could also get boring fast though so the portion size in the bento was perfect.

Potato croquette: didn't expect this to be crunchy & it wasn't. Came with a baby BBQ sauce packet and it went well with the croquette. Just OK. Potato was cooked all the way through and seasoned well - it's probably better fresh!

Agedashi tofu: I forgot to dip this with the sauce when I ate it so I can't judge this fairly but the texture was good! 

Surprisingly my favorite was the green bean salad. It came with thinly julienned carrots and the light sesame/mayo dressing was SO good........

Definitely coming back to try more items next time!
They also have curry and soup here which seem to be worth trying as well.

excerpts: Then they have about 10 options listed under each category so you can basically mix and match your own bento boxes essentially.
They've also got a couple donburis and other options as well.
I went with pork katsu and mabo tofu salad with rice and also grabbed a salmon onigiri.
bento.author: Jasmine X.
bento.review:
Actually pretty good. I've heard a lot of good things about Delica but remember being a little turned off when I walked by once because I tend to distrust Asian fusion and they had some crazy Japanese + Californian creation that made me a little worried. Decided to give it a shot today since I was in a rush and wanted something that I could just grab and go.

They've got a pretty expansive menu actually. There're combo variations such as main + salad + rice, main + salad + soup, main + salad + salad, etc. Then they have about 10 options listed under each category so you can basically mix and match your own bento boxes essentially. They've also got a couple donburis and other options as well. I went with pork katsu and mabo tofu salad with rice and also grabbed a salmon onigiri. Quick pro tip: if you don't really know what you're getting yourself into just from reading the menu, just look at the displays since they have all the mains in the display -- e.g. I originally thought about chicken dumplings but then saw that they looked more like chicken meatballs

Overall, the food didn't look that amazing, but it was actually pretty good -- would definitely come back. Pork katsu was just pork katsu, pretty typical -- they had the sauce drizzled on it, but the mabo tofu was pretty solid. It looked a little gimpy and not delicious but actually tasted SO good. A little citrusy, very flavorful, and just a salad with tofu, glass noodles (forgot what they're exactly called in English... but the clear noodles basically) and lettuce. It actually complemented the katsu really well since it offset the heaviness of it. I really dug it. The portion size was also pretty good since it kept me full after a long day of walking around pride festivities and was only priced around $8 or so which I thought was a great bargain.

The salmon onigiri was a bit disappointing so I would probably pass on that. But besides that, the service was pretty friendly, they were really efficient, and it was a really solid deal. I'd definitely be coming here for lunch all the time if I worked near here.

tldr; japanese food meets california -- have some faith, even if the food sounds weird it might be pretty good!

excerpts: Bento box for $13+ is a rip off.
bento.author: Sahil B.
bento.review:
Bento box for $13+ is a rip off. It used to be $10 not worth it anymore.

I will never come back here and wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

excerpts: there is a purely to-go line with bento boxes and the like, and then a line for the salads and other stuff.
there are a few options for lunch combinations - salads, soup, rice, main, etc.
i got a combo of three salads - corn, green bean, and mabo tofu.
they were pretty yummy, but very saucy and definitely not as healthy as i would have liked.
there's seating right outside delica, but i would choose some of the outdoor seats by the water :)
bento.author: Christina L.
bento.review: came to this spot for lunch yesterday with a friend - maybe my 3rd time here. there are so many options it's a little overwhelming! there is a purely to-go line with bento boxes and the like, and then a line for the salads and other stuff. there are a few options for lunch combinations - salads, soup, rice, main, etc.  i got a combo of three salads - corn, green bean, and mabo tofu. they were pretty yummy, but very saucy and definitely not as healthy as i would have liked. there's seating right outside delica, but i would choose some of the outdoor seats by the water :)

excerpts: Based on the photos and prior reviews, I was excited to try the 9 item bento.
Loved that there was variety but everything fell below my expectations.
The pieces of sushi were dry while the small bits of salad were almost the same w/ very few distinguishable ingredients.
bento.author: Julie L.
bento.review: Based on the photos and prior reviews, I was excited to try the 9 item bento. Loved that there was variety but everything fell below my expectations. The pieces of sushi were dry while the small bits of salad were almost the same w/ very few distinguishable ingredients. Ordered the shrimp cake, crab croquette and 3 chicken dumplings. While the shrimp cake and crab croquette were equally enjoyable w/ the deliciously moist filling, we both didn't like the chicken  dumpling. Not only did it not look like a dumpling, I just couldn't find anything that is worth $2+/piece...especially the flavor. We also shared a miso soup and the salmon chowder but the portion was ultra small for a bowl size at $7.50. Flavors were "just ok".

excerpts: They have pre-packaged and make your own bento boxes.
I always get the bento boxes when I go there.

I typically get the 4 item bento box:

Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad
bento.author: Tanya C.
bento.review:
Delica is a Japanese deli located in the Ferry Building.  They have pre-packaged and make your own bento boxes.  You can also buy individual items by the piece or weight.

I always get the bento boxes when I go there.  You can choose from 4 ($9.75 - 1 fried, 2 salads, rice), 5 ($9.75 - 3 salads, half shrimp cake, 1 chicken dumpling) or 9 ($11.00 - 5 salads, 3 salmon, 1 chicken dumpling) items. 

 I typically get the 4 item bento box:

Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad - This potato salad looks bizarre, but is super delicious.  The wasabi mayo in it is so good!  It also has edamame and snap peas in it.

Green Bean Salad - comes with a sesame dressing and is really good as well.

For the fried item, I usually get the chicken dumpling or the tonkatsu.

There's usually a line here, but it goes fast.  They have plenty of  seating.  A nice lunch option if you are in the area.

excerpts:
After filling my bags with wholesome, fresh, organic vegetables, I'll stop by Delica to pick up a bento box for lunch.  

Bento boxes contain samples of the salads, sushi and fried items.
bento.author: Melissa L.
bento.review:
After filling my bags with wholesome, fresh, organic vegetables, I'll stop by Delica to pick up a bento box for lunch.  

They offer a variety of salads (burdock and lotus roots and the wasabi garlic potato are my favorites), rice bowls, soups, sushi and deep fried meats, seafood and vegetables.  Bento boxes contain samples of the salads, sushi and fried items.  

Although the prices are a tad high, the ingredients are fresh and flavorful.   I've never been disappointed with my meals here.  You are paying for the quality of the food, location, their attention to detail around the preparation of their dishes.

My only wish is that they offered greater variety in their dishes from time to time.  Or, I just need to pop in for dinner instead of just lunch.

excerpts: Love their create your own bento idea!
2 salads, one fried item and rice.
bento.author: Amber S.
bento.review:
Love their create your own bento idea! 2 salads, one fried item and rice. 
My favorite is the crab croquette (& tartar sauce!), green bean with creamy sesame dressing and hijiki salad!!

Their carrot ginger soup is a great way to get your veggie intake too! Would give them 5 stars if they only had brown rice...!

excerpts: Just think of delica as being your mom going into the kitchen, grabbing the seasonal vegetables and preparing it in a creative way, and sending it all with you in a bento for school.
bento.author: Natalie C.
bento.review:
If you have ever wondered what home cooked Japanese food tastes like, this is it! 

I'd have to say that after going over to my Japanese friends' house for a number of dinners and doing a homestay in Japan, I might know a thing or two... Not much, but a bit. 

The meal I got brought back lots of memories of combining things that you might think don't go together , but end up being great! 

Don't go into it looking for the typical lunch special you find at most places. Just think of delica as being your mom going into the kitchen, grabbing the seasonal vegetables and preparing it in a creative way, and sending it all with you in a bento for school.

The green bean salad was a surprise fav. I felt a little worried for some reason... But it was creamy and delicious. I also loved the use of takenoko and celery in another salad! I got to sample the wasabi potato salad and regretted not grabbing some. Definitely going back!

excerpts: It's a healthy and fast option for lunch, offering a mix of bento boxes, sushi rolls, salads, croquettes, soups, and noodle dishes.
Everything I've had here if flavorful, tasty, and very filling.
bento.author: Jennifer W.
bento.review:
Californian-inspired Japanese deli catering to the lunchtime working crowd. It's a healthy and fast option for lunch, offering a mix of bento boxes, sushi rolls, salads, croquettes, soups, and noodle dishes. Everything I've had here if flavorful, tasty, and very filling. I always get combo #2, which is 2 salads+salad or soup, and at just under $10, a good lunch option.

I usually get the burdock salad, sesame spinach, eggplant nasu or mabo tofu salad. Tofu patty and crab croquette are also good add-ons.

excerpts: you can pick up and go as well as a pretty flexible bento menu of options and ways to pick and choose.
bento.author: Melody T.
bento.review:
Not sure how I missed this place in the ferry building for the past 3 years. Almost embarrassing. 

I can appreciate their existence in the ferry building - provides more variety amongst the  pricey sambos at cowgirl creamery/sidekick, acme and boccalone. 

Spinach and seaweed salad - yum! Could be a little more flavorful/sesame flavor heavier. Pabu's is phenomenal!

I thought the chicken and tofu patty was pretty bland. I'm curious to try the tofu steak and chicken dumplings next time. 

It's nice that they have to go bentos you can pick up and go as well as a pretty flexible bento menu of options and ways to pick and choose. 

First experience was okay, but definitely worth another try.

excerpts: A delightful Japanese-California fusion with bento boxes and salads in amazing twists.
bento.author: Christina N.
bento.review:
A delightful Japanese-California fusion with bento boxes and salads in amazing twists.

I came here during lunch hour so we had one of those grab and go boxes which was decent enough. Unfortunately, I'm not a big fan of this kinda fusion and would very much prefer traditional Japanese instead.

I'll probably return again since the food isnt bad :)

excerpts: One of the best bento boxes I've had so far.
bento.author: Jen P.
bento.review:
One of the best bento boxes I've had so far. 

- Spinach and Sesame Salad: Pretty straightforward, but cooked in dashi broth.

- Spicy Burdock and Lotus Root Salad: Loved this. It's a mix of so many veggies; there's also konnyaku, onions, celery, carrots, and other greens tossed in there. Everything is thinly sliced, crunchy, light, and flavorful.

- Fried Shrimp Cake: You know the kind where it's all breading and there's only a few tiny pieces of shrimp inside? NOT the case here. Instead, the entire block is shrimp and covered in very thin crispy panko. Yum.

Being a person who prefers eating meat over veggies, I was surprised I liked this place more than usual, and I think that says a lot. Ingredients are high quality and fresh!

excerpts: I always grab a bento box of their "sozai".
Each box contains a lovely assortment of rolls and vegetable salads.
Perfect for snacking!
bento.author: Hieu H.
bento.review:
Great little Japanese delicatessan tucked near the end of the Ferry Market building.  

I always grab a bento box of their "sozai". Each box contains a lovely assortment of rolls and vegetable salads.  Perfect for snacking!

excerpts: When my husband asked for a bento instead, girl behind the counter rolled her eyes.
When he asked what his options were, she sighed, 'I don't know, man..." and waited for him to figure it out.
It was apparently paining her to do her job.
Another guy assembled my bento, at least he smiled and tried to help me out.
bento.author: Lauren D.
bento.review:
We were craving sushi, but they had run out completely. When my husband asked for a bento instead, girl behind the counter rolled her eyes. When he asked what his options were, she sighed, 'I don't know, man..." and waited for him to figure it out. It was apparently paining her to do her job. Another guy assembled my bento, at least he smiled and tried to help me out. I got an assortment of salads and some cold, disappointing chicken. 

We were overcharged, about 30 dollars total for 2 bentos and 2 drinks. I just couldn't believe the attitude and confusion among the staff here. Apparently it had been a busy day, which I understand, but when you work in food service at a high traffic location, you figure out a way to help people and not be a total bitch.

excerpts: I got the pre-assorted bento and it was probably one of the healthiest meals I've had in San Francisco!
I really like how unique each of the dishes were but the food was pretty bland .
My personal favorite was the potato croquette.
I'll be coming here when I want a light and filling lunch, but probably not when I'm looking for food to savor.
bento.author: Vivian W.
bento.review: 5 stars for variety and 3 for flavor. I got the pre-assorted bento and it was probably one of the healthiest meals I've had in San Francisco! I really like how unique each of the dishes were but the food was pretty bland . My personal favorite was the potato croquette. I'll be coming here when I want a light and filling lunch, but probably not when I'm looking for food to savor.

excerpts: I love Delica, I love that Delica is authentic with traditional Japanese salads/sides/bento boxes, and I love that it's SO close to where I work and live.
When I've stopped by for lunch, I've picked up with their Pork Katsu bento box without having to wait in a typically long line.
bento.author: Lisa I.
bento.review: I love Delica, I love that Delica is authentic with traditional Japanese salads/sides/bento boxes, and I love that it's SO close to where I work and live.  When I've stopped by for lunch, I've picked up with their Pork Katsu bento box without having to wait in a typically long line.  It comes with a few delicious pieces of pork katsu with their tonkatsu sauce, white rice, Hijiki and Soybean Salad, and their Spicy Burdock Root Salad.  So delicious! Sure the box sets you back $9.75 plus tax, but it's definitely a complete meal.  Their combos where you can order a variety of salad/side combinations is also really cool!  Anyway, this is a great place for lunch during the weekend or weekday! I highly recommend it!

excerpts: If you're really in a rush to get back to the salt mines, there are bento boxes and onigiri to the left side.
bento.author: Kevin L.
bento.review:
My go-to place in the Ferry Building!

Even when the lines for lunch are long, the staff is efficient enough to keep things zipping along. The menu can be confusing if it's your first time (for example, one item is "SALAD + SALAD + SOUP or SALAD"), but it's really just that you can pick any combo of salads, main, and/or soup that you want. I usually go with the standard two salads plus a main.

The wasabi potato salad, burdock salad, and the hijiki seaweed salad are great, though the hijiki might not be as strongly dressed as people expect. For main dish, I like getting the tofu and chicken patty. This comes out to just under $10, so a tad pricey for lunch, but one of the better deals in Ferry Buildinglandia.

If you're really in a rush to get back to the salt mines, there are bento boxes and onigiri to the left side. Just snag one and head straight to the cashier. 

They also do soup noodles, but I haven't tried that yet.

excerpts:
This place is well known for deli and bento boxes, but you should also try dinner.
Yes, they are open for dinner from 5:00pm till 10:00pm on weekdays with happy hour for 5:00pm-7:00pm.
The owner is pure Japanese and they serve real Japanese dishes.
bento.author: Tomomi K.
bento.review:
This place is well known for deli and bento boxes, but you should also try dinner.
Yes, they are open for dinner from 5:00pm till 10:00pm on weekdays with happy hour for 5:00pm-7:00pm.
The owner is pure Japanese and they serve real Japanese dishes.  
I hope my review helps since they don't have much information of dinner on their website.


*Food - 4.5 stars
They have authentic dishes and some original dishes, that are perfectly arranged and seasoned, and everything is DELICIOUS!  We ordered:

- Omakase Sushi (12 pieces) and some individual sushi 
They pick seasonal fresh fish for Omakase.  
If you are into Uni(Sea Urchin), you MUST try Uni!  I would say one of the best Uni you can have in Bay Area.  It is from Fort Bragg and so sweet, rich, and it melts in your mouth. 
Saba (mackerel) from Japan was amazingly delicious when I went there. (5/9/2013). Saba for sushi is usually served after salted and soaked in vinegar, but their Saba was super fresh and it was served just raw.  We rarely have it even in Japan.

- Grilled Avocado
Great appetizer dish!  Simply grilled and served with Daikon Oroshi, sauce and spice on top of it.  Unexpectedly great combination.

- Kobe Beef Tataki
Enjoy the tender beef with a lot of green onions and sweet sauce.

- Kale Salad
Served with slices of cheese and apple.

- Grilled Squid
Typical Japanese tapas dish.  A whole squid served with mayonnaise on the side.  Tender and chewy at the same time.  

- Tsuke men
OMG, delicious! You dip noodles in the broth with a lot of mushroom.
One of the popular ways to have ramen noodles in Japan.

- Baked Curry
Caution: very very very hot!!  Ouch!  It is good, but don't rush!  Don't get yourself burned!


*Service - 3.5 stars
Unfortunately, I have to say there is some room to improve.
One of the waitresses doesn't know the menu well.  They often mix up the orders.
They have the happy hour menu and a bit complicated rules ordering with the regular menu if you go there before 7:00pm, which is confusing.


Even having said that, I am a big fan of this place!  It is absolutely worth trying if you have a liking for Japanese food.  
Enjoy great Sushi and tapas!  I guarantee you won't regret!  
For reservation, just call them.

excerpts:
I love Japanese style bento boxes and donburis!

For grab and go there's usually onigiri and premade bento boxes.
bento.author: Michelle T.
bento.review:
Lines here are RIDIC but worth the wait!

I love Japanese style bento boxes and donburis!

My favorite here is the Ginger Beef Bowl (Natural Japanese supreme ground Kobe Beef and ginger served with shredded egg and steamed rice. Topped with green onion) It is full of protein, filling, a good price, and most importantly SOOO delicious. 

They usually have this bowl as grab and pay so no need to wait in the same RIDIC line as those who are waiting to order from the menu whatever dish their hearts desire. 

For grab and go there's usually onigiri and premade bento boxes.

Some other items I love here are:

*Organic Agedashi Tofu Steak: Silken (Kinugoshi) firm tofu is lightly dusted with potato starch and then deep fried until golden brown. It's then served in a hot tentsuyu broth made od dashi, mirin, and sho-yu (Japanese soy sauce), and topped with grated daikon. Though it is deep fried, it does not taste heavy! It is perfectly fried!

*Spicy Burdock Root Salad: A spicy mix of braised burdock and konnyaku (mountain potato) tossed with thin slices of white onion, celery, julienne carrots, and wild mizuna.
This isn't really spicy but WHATEVER it is amazing!!!

*Hijiki and Soybean Salad: Hijiki (seaweed rich in calcium, iron, and fiber) mixed with dried soybeans, edamame, konnyaku (mountain potato), daikon, wild mizuna, fried tofu, and kuko (wolfberry) cooked with soy sauce.

Gosh, thinking about all the delicious food is making me so hungry.

excerpts: They sell both vegetarian and normal fish lover's bento boxes for between 10-16$, as well as pre-packaged sushi and containers of sides and rice balls for folks in a rush who just want to grab and go.
They additionally offer their glass case menu items in containers by weight, as well as at least one hot menu item, and two soup choices.

I've had the chicken salad, the large bento box, the hijiki salad, wasabi potato salad, green beans, chicken dumpling, sushi, basically everything that doesn't contain pork, and it was all absolutely delicious.
The hijiki salad is my favorite.
You can easily let your stomach take over and spend way too much money on way too much food, so be careful.
Pick one or two things and come back another time to try more.
All their menu items are more filling than they look!
bento.author: Kaia V.
bento.review: The food at Delica is so good, I can't help but eat here for lunch every day I'm in SF. They sell both vegetarian and normal fish lover's bento boxes for between 10-16$, as well as pre-packaged sushi and containers of sides and rice balls for folks in a rush who just want to grab and go. They additionally offer their glass case menu items in containers by weight, as well as at least one hot menu item, and two soup choices. I've had the chicken salad, the large bento box, the hijiki salad, wasabi potato salad, green beans, chicken dumpling, sushi, basically everything that doesn't contain pork, and it was all absolutely delicious. The hijiki salad is my favorite. You can easily let your stomach take over and spend way too much money on way too much food, so be careful. Pick one or two things and come back another time to try more. All their menu items are more filling than they look!

excerpts: Bento Boxes are my happy place.
I had entree + salad + rice box.
bento.author: Karen C.
bento.review:
I love all the mix-and-matching you can do at Delica... Bento Boxes are my happy place. I had entree + salad + rice box. The green bean salad was ridiculously good, and the shrimp nest thing was tasty as well. 

Definitely a great quick spot to grab a bite for a decent price while visiting the Ferry Building.

excerpts: The bento boxes ($9.75) are a nice way to sample a little bit of everything.

Some of my favorites are the ginger beef bowl http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/G2I9_EOXAx7AUbmVPCfyCg/l ($8.75, ginger seasoned ground beef with scrambled eggs) and ginger pork bowl (grilled pork cutlets).
The beef curry ($8.50) does have a nice amount of heat.
The salads are a bit too expensive in my opinion ($12-$15 per pound), so I prefer to get the combinations that come in the bento instead.
bento.author: Luis C.
bento.review:
I'm actually glad that they now refer to themselves as DeliCA or DELICA, which is a much more clear and straightforward name. The "rf-1" part of their name (derived from parent firm Rock Field Co.) was a bit weird. That's a name more suitable for a car, I think.

Yes, it's a little expensive, but nice place when u want something other than a sandwich for lunch. This is a modern Japanese delicatessen, selling their own high-end version of sozai cuisine (small plates of comfort food) and a few traditional dishes. The bento boxes ($9.75) are a nice way to sample a little bit of everything. Some of my favorites are the ginger beef bowl http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/G2I9_EOXAx7AUbmVPCfyCg/l ($8.75, ginger seasoned ground beef with scrambled eggs) and ginger pork bowl (grilled pork cutlets). The beef curry ($8.50) does have a nice amount of heat. The salads are a bit too expensive in my opinion ($12-$15 per pound), so I prefer to get the combinations that come in the bento instead.

Once in a while I like to buy one of the croquettes ($1.75-$4) - remember to ask for one of the sauces, tartar or tomato (only when u buy the more expensive shrimp croquette, but I manage to get it anyways). Also don't forget dessert (around $2.50), their seasonal pudding cups (so far: pana cotta, green tea, custard with fruit, avocado topped with mango, etc.) are really good, delicate and flavorful.

excerpts: My favorite are their 'bento' lunch boxes where you can pick soup/salad/entree.
bento.author: Laurel K.
bento.review:
Great place for a reasonably healthy boxed lunch. This is one of my go-to spots during the week if I have time to schlep over to the Ferry Building, and our office gets it catered a fair amount. My favorite are their 'bento' lunch boxes where you can pick soup/salad/entree. 

Recommend:
Sesame spinach salad
Green bean salad
Carrot ginger soup!!
Wasabi mashed potatoes (HOLY MOLY so good and creamy, craving them now)
Potato cakes, but only if you eat them with the tonkatsu (or whatever it's called ) sauce they serve on the side
Salmon sushi

Ok:
Chicken dumplings
Tofu triangle things

Avoid:
Roast beef sushi...just weird

excerpts: Great selection, sushi, bento boxes, soups, curries etc.
Plenty of veggie options.
bento.author: Crystal Y.
bento.review: Tasty but overpriced. Great selection, sushi, bento boxes, soups, curries etc. Plenty of veggie options. I got the mushroom curry and it was delicious, but for $10, I wish there was some veggies or tofu in there, instead of just button mushrooms and thin lotus slices.

excerpts: Not very much seating (that's the Ferry Building for you), but this place has a lot of great grab-and-go bento box options, as well as great combos.
The menu is a good mixture of fried treats and healthy sushi options, so you can indulge or be healthy as you see fit.
All around a solid lunch option for FiDi worker bees!
bento.author: Katie P.
bento.review: Yummy! I went here on a lunch date with a friend from college, and we were happy. Not very much seating (that's the Ferry Building for you), but this place has a lot of great grab-and-go bento box options, as well as great combos. The menu is a good mixture of fried treats and healthy sushi options, so you can indulge or be healthy as you see fit. All around a solid lunch option for FiDi worker bees!

excerpts: Maybe it's less stressful to just get a pre-made bento box for around the same price.
The salads were quite fresh and unique, especially the wasabi garlic potato.
If you aren't a fan of wasabi, I probably wouldn't suggest it.
The flavors come in phases and the wasabi kicks in last.
bento.author: Jessica F.
bento.review:
The Ferry Building is a constant reminder that my paycheck cries every time I eat out, especially for FiDi lunches. Delica is a Japanese-fusion takeout lunch spot that gets pretty busy during lunch hour. The menu is very overwhelming and confusing if you are coming here for the first time. It repeats "SALAD" to a distressing degree. Should I have a Main + SALAD + SALAD or a triple-threat SALAD + SALAD + SALAD? How many SALADs are in the display case? What's in each SALAD?

I ended up giving a frazzled order for a Main (Tonkatsu) + SALAD (Spicy Burdock) + SALAD (Wasabi Garlic Potato), which cost me about $10. Maybe it's less stressful to just get a pre-made bento box for around the same price. The salads were quite fresh and unique, especially the wasabi garlic potato. If you aren't a fan of wasabi, I probably wouldn't suggest it. The flavors come in phases and the wasabi kicks in last.The Tonkatsu was cold and not the best, so I would probably recommend you avoid it.

You can buy salad by the pound and pay for individual "main" items. I believe there is a sit down portion of Delica? It's all very stressful and confusing for a novice. I did enjoy my food here, but the prices are high for a conservatively-filled take out box.

excerpts: love the pre-arranged bento boxes!
bento.author: Nattie X.
bento.review:
I was pleasantly surprised by this little market deli-ish spot in the ferry building. 
Didn't realize they served Japanese food until I walked inside. Love that all the food is pre-made (no waiting) and displayed right in front of you. Also love that you can order everything by the piece and try half the menu. 

Loved: 
crab croquette
beef curry
mapo tofu salad (genius)

the chicken meatballs were a little dry

would definitely come back again to sample the other half of the menu. love the pre-arranged bento boxes!

excerpts:
salads on the high end
-vegetarian bento boxes available.
-ingredients

fresh
-outstanding service.
-will try a soup, noodle next time or.....
bento.author: Victor G.
bento.review:
Delica is japanese food with california nuances. got some eats from the deli.

sampling: 
-potato croquette(1.75)
fresh, small potato bits, fried. fresh
-shrimp cake(4)
whole crunchy fresh shrimp with mayo based sauce.
a version of crab cakes.
-chicken dumpling(2)
fried, fresh and delicately flavored.  maybe that's why tonkatsu sauce given.
-rating 3.5 for freshness of ingredients. food not highly seasoned. . 

temakI:
-artisan salads on the high end
-vegetarian bento boxes available.
-ingredients  fresh
-outstanding service.
-will try a soup, noodle next time or.....

excerpts: Three words: vegetarian bento box.
Green bean salad, hijiki with soy beans, mushroom/carrot/daikon sushi roll, lightly fried tofu with sauce, marinated daikon salad with carrots and greens.
bento.author: Julia D.
bento.review:
Three words: vegetarian bento box. Green bean salad, hijiki with soy beans, mushroom/carrot/daikon sushi roll, lightly fried tofu with sauce, marinated daikon salad with carrots and greens. One more word: AMAZING.

Also, the potato croquette was super fantastic. 

I will most likely return and eat their entire supply of...everything.

excerpts: For the bento boxes.
I had an appointment in the am, so was going into my client's office later than normal.
I stopped at the Ferry Building to pick up a lunch to go and boy
it didn't disappoint.
Hello delicious tender tsukune, tastiest kinipira gobo, creamy wasabi mashed potatoes, and hijiki salad (which i normally hate) that I actually ate and would go back for.
Yum yum yum.
bento.author: Soy P.
bento.review: For the bento boxes. I had an appointment in the am, so was going into my client's office later than normal. I stopped at the Ferry Building to pick up a lunch to go and boy it didn't disappoint. Hello delicious tender tsukune, tastiest kinipira gobo, creamy wasabi mashed potatoes, and hijiki salad (which i normally hate) that I actually ate and would go back for. Yum yum yum.

excerpts:
$9.50 - Bento box with five items
$7.75 - Regular size curry
$1.50 - Potato coroke
bento.author: トモ T.
bento.review:
I will tell a big secret - Delica RF1 is a VERY Japanese place.  Of all the SF Japanese restaurants, this place could best compete if they sold the same food in Japan, evident by the fact that you could find RF-1 at the basement floor of department stores in Tokyo (see downloaded pic).  It is not Japanese food from 1970's (like many J-town restaurants).  It gives you a small insight into some of the popular foods in modern Japan.  I am not saying RF-1 is the most popular type of food found in Tokyo as there are vast variety of other options available.  When transplants from Tokyo finds Delica, they are so happy to see a piece of Japan they miss.  

Many people are surprised to hear this, because Delica offers food seemly Americanized.  Nope.  Americanized means taste was altered to fit the likings of American customers.  Food at Delica, along with many places in Tokyo, has been Japanized.  The taste was altered to the likings of Japanese customers - altered so much that it is now considered Japanese food.  Items in this category include: Ramen, Kasutera, Tonkatsu, Hamburg, egg sandwich, etc.

What does this mean?  Well, you might not like their food.  Selling food that was designed to meet Japanese people's preferences to Americans is a crazy idea.  But, they opened a branch here, probably more for marketing purposes rather than for profits.  Japanese companies like to show the equity holders that they are expanding abroad, just like Beard Papa.  I don't care, because I am happy that it is here.   

Like I said, 80% of the Japanese restaurants in SF wouldn't survive if they moved to Tokyo.  Just like San Francisco, restaurant industry in Tokyo is fiercely competitive, so if you are serving food that tastes like something I could cook at home (80% of SF J-Food), you are done.  All you need to know is that Delica's food is surviving the competition in Tokyo.  The food is especially popular among OLs (office ladies) (yes, the word is sexist, but I didn't invent the word).  Don't get me wrong, the traditional Japanese food like tempura and unaju is still popular in Japan, but food in Japan has done though significant transformations since 1945.  It is now quite diverse - while the passion for food has not changed.        

Delica is a creation of Rock Field Co., Ltd.   The founder, Mr. Iwata Kozo, did a direct translation of his kanji characters and named the company Rock (Iwa) Field (ta).  Although the company sounds western, it is completely Japanese company.  The company has an impressive mission - to address the environment, safety, and freshness of Japanese food.  The founder had concerns about the direction of Japanese diet and is making the effort to change for the better.  Positioning Delica branch at the Ferry Building is fitting to their theme.  Where else would you find beef curry that uses Prather Ranch Meat?  Mushroom curry that uses Far West Fungi mushrooms?     

SEATS:  Very limited.  Find a place outside to sit and eat under the sun.

PRICE:  There is a price to the environment, safety, and freshness.  If you want cheaper food, look for MSG infused dishes at cheaper restaurants.  Expect to pay $10-14 for lunch.
$9.50 - Bento box with five items
$7.75 - Regular size curry
$1.50 - Potato coroke

excerpts: The different bento box selections will fascinate you on looks alone.
I haven't tried any of the bento box selections, but in time I look forward to sampling many of them.
bento.author: Wilhelm Y.
bento.review:
DELICA rf-1 is one of my favorite restaurants among all of the chic eateries located inside the Ferry Building.  It's informal.  You order up your selections at or near the cashier station.  You get your food in recyclable take-out containers.  You grab some compostable utensils.  You find a seat or take it on the go.  The food is beautifully prepared, and the spectacular flavors will surprise you.

Everything I've tried to date has been delicious whether it be the Organic Mabo Tofu Salad, the signature Roast Beef Sushi or the Wild Salmon and Sesame Genmai Rice Ball.

The Shrimp Curry is probably my favorite selection here.  Depending on my appetite I usually go for the regular serving, but I have stuffed myself with the large portion on occasion.  In a mild brown curry sauce expect to find lots of firm baby shrimp, chunks of soft zucchini and tomato pieces nearly melted away.  They use seasonal vegetables in their curry dishes so you may not get the same zucchini and tomato combination that they've been serving up lately.  The curry is served with a generous portion of hot steamed rice to the side allowing you to eat each part separately or all mixed together.

The Potato and White Corn Croquette is outstanding.  It reminds me of the deep-fried taro root pastries found at many Chinese dim sum houses, but it is far less oily.  These are deep-fried also.  It's a smooth, creamy potato center with a delicate crispy, crumbly shell on the outside.  Bite into the croquette and you will discover soft, creamy kernels of white corn inside.  

Most of the prepared food is on display inside the crystal clear deli cases and each looks like a different work of art.  The different bento box selections will fascinate you on looks alone.  I haven't tried any of the bento box selections, but in time I look forward to sampling many of them.

It's not uncommon to see visitors inside photographing the food.  Toro E and several other reviewers have captured some of the beauty of the food in the photo section.  In fact Toro E writes one of my favorite reviews for DELICA rf-1.  This can be found at http://www.yelp.com/biz/delica-rf-1-san-francisco?q=Toro+E .

excerpts: Bento boxes are a terrific option on a warm SF day (you gotta time this....
a psychic may help), buy a Bento & take outside, sit on a bench (ignore the homeless crazies) and enjoy the Bento & view.
Have had a few lunches @ Delica... each has been good.
This is a Japanese Fusion deli, however with fresh ingredients, modern preparation, tasty options.
bento.author: Matsuo U.
bento.review:
Easy & tasty. Bento boxes are a terrific option on a warm SF day (you gotta time this.... a psychic may help), buy a Bento & take outside, sit on a bench (ignore the homeless crazies) and enjoy the Bento & view. Have had a few lunches @ Delica... each has been good. This is a Japanese Fusion deli, however with fresh ingredients, modern preparation, tasty options.  Their menu makes me hungry:  http://www.delicasf.com/menu.html

It ain't cheap, but unless you are a Ferry Building virgin ( ie. never entered the Ferry Building ... know what I mean?) then you know there is nothing cheap in the Ferry Building. Want cheap food? Take the F line street car, go to Market Street around 4th or 5th street. (ok, I admit to never eating "down there" but, have seen the gaudy hawking signs),

Weekends at the F. building are madness ( read crowded ). All the lonely people (oooooh there was a song like that) from Marin & the East Bay flock there, and the "foodies" looking for the perfect peach, tomato, potato at the "farmers market", some complaining "oooh, its sooo expensive."  and then exclaiming "but it is worth it".

excerpts: And SO many choices - bento boxes, sushi, rice bowls, cold sides, soups, hot sides, and so much more.
bento.author: Cindy T.
bento.review:
I wish we had something similar to Delica in Silicon Valley. It's fresh, organic and healthy! And SO many choices - bento boxes, sushi, rice bowls, cold sides, soups, hot sides, and so much more. We ended up getting an agedashi tofu steak, roast beef nigiri, chicken dumpling and miso soup. We enjoyed everything. The flavors were spot on and you could taste the freshness and lightness of the food. Definitely makes for a good lunch spot.

Prices are a bit pricey, but what isn't at the Ferry Building?

excerpts: Fork over $10, grab bento box, and you are out the door in minutes.
They have veggie & non-veggie bento boxes with 4 or 5 items.
bento.author: Amy C.
bento.review:
Delica rf-1 is my go to place when I want something 1) quick, 2) fresh, 3) tasty, 4) healthy-ish and 5) Japanese-ish.

Fork over $10, grab bento box, and you are out the door in minutes.  Either back to your office (boo) or to sit outside and enjoy the sunny weather (woo!).    

They have veggie & non-veggie bento boxes with 4 or 5 items.  Like the Chinese Chicken Salad (I thought this was a Japanese deli?), Burdock & Lotus Root Salad, rice (white or rice salad), shrimp cake, etc.  

But whatever you do, don't miss out on the chicken dumplings and the AMAZING wasabi and garlic potato salad!

excerpts: If you don't feel like waiting in line, you can choose from many of their pre-packaged bento boxes or rolls.
Everything looked mysterious but what caught my eye was the spicy tuna roll and oddly enough the roast beef nigiri.
Twisting the Japanese cuisine in this way may not jive well with the authenticians but it definitely fits in with the Ferry Building crowd.
bento.author: Shannon L.
bento.review:
Eating at Delica's is equally satisfying and dissastisfying, as in you feel good eating but you just want a burger afterwards.  You know that everything is good for you and loaded with nutrients.  I mean come on, any place that offers a lunch combo consisting of THREE salads is up there on the health meter.  Even when I tried to slightly de-healthify my lunch combo by getting the one fried item and two salads, it STILL didn't work.  

Despite my urges to get the sweet sesame chicken as my fried item, I had to veer away from my inner Panda Express and get what I thought looked the most visually magnificent: the Kaki Age.  It is probably the largest tempura fried item I have ever seen.  I mean it's definitely not something you hold in your hand or eat in one bite.  You have to break it apart and for some reason, the shredded vegetables binds it so firmly together that it becomes quite difficult to separate.  I do like that big pieces of white shrimp are incorporated into it.  Unfortunately, all these aren't fried on the spot so they've been sitting in the glass counter and is missing the aspect that I like most about tempura and fried foods in general, the fresh friedness.

As for the Hijiki Soybean Salad and the Mascarpone Corn Salad, I definitely preferred the latter since I'm a die hard corn fan.  I like the creaminess from the mascarpone and a lot of the kernels stick together so it's easy to eat even with chopsticks.  Not to sound redundant but the Hijiki was really healthy and actually makes your body feel good when you're eating it but may be weird if you're not familiar with the ingredients.

If you don't feel like waiting in line, you can choose from many of their pre-packaged bento boxes or rolls.  Everything looked mysterious but what caught my eye was the spicy tuna roll and oddly enough the roast beef nigiri.  Twisting the Japanese cuisine in this way may not jive well with the authenticians but it definitely fits in with the Ferry Building crowd.

excerpts: I grabbed the vegetable bento, which came with agedashi tofu, croquette and a few different types of salads, which were ALL really delicious.
The agedashi tofu was great, slightly different twist to your traditional style, but so tasty.
I would love to come again!
bento.author: Jenn T.
bento.review: This is an interesting little unique japanese deli.  They have japanese food with a twist to it and serve different types of cool bentos and sushi rolls.  I grabbed the vegetable bento, which came with agedashi tofu, croquette and a few different types of salads, which were ALL really delicious.  The agedashi tofu was great, slightly different twist to your traditional style, but so tasty.  I would love to come again!

excerpts: They have a wide selection of dishes both vegetarian, non-vegetarian, Vegan, and pre-made bento boxes!
Fresh, flavorful, different than other bentos.
bento.author: Tanya T.
bento.review:
They have a wide selection of dishes both vegetarian, non-vegetarian, Vegan, and pre-made bento boxes! Fresh, flavorful, different than other bentos.
My favorite is the salmon chowder, and the Soybean/Hijiki Salad.  The food is very fresh and tasty, but it comes with a price!

excerpts: Thanks to their slick move of having bento boxes ready to go, I snagged the one labeled vegan, paid, and bounced back to start eating while my friends hadn't even gotten a chance to order yet.
The bento looked badass however the tofu was lacking, the salads were OK though.
Still, a solid and healthy meal for around $9 is a success in my book, especially at a farmers market where you can seemingly drop $20 every few steps.
bento.author: Justin N.
bento.review:
I guess I'd have to say the food looks a tad better than it really is, however it's still a solid choice.

I had out of towner friends who were bedazzled by the farmers market. They wanted to taste all the food and if you've ever hit the Ferry Building Farmers Market you know that can mean waiting in line for quite some time. Too long at times if you ask me.

My friends got into lines and I headed over to Delica. Thanks to their slick move of having bento boxes ready to go, I snagged the one labeled vegan, paid, and bounced back to start eating while my friends hadn't even gotten a chance to order yet.

Yes the farmers market grub is good, but sometimes those lines are just ridiculous. The bento looked badass however the tofu was lacking, the salads were OK though. Still, a solid and healthy meal for around $9 is a success in my book, especially at a farmers market where you can seemingly drop $20 every few steps.

excerpts:
1 Salmon Onigiri
1 Sweet & Spicy Chicken Bento
My friend got the bento and the onigiri.
Both were made with very fresh ingredients
but I wouldn't argue that they were particularly stand out compared to the other two.

However, you really do pay a premium when you eat at the Ferry Building and while most of the time I'd give a place like this four stars because I loved what I had so much, the bento seems to be a bit hit or miss.
bento.author: Andrew B.
bento.review:
My buddy and I were cruising the Ferry building and as we are both fans of Japanese food, we thought we would try this place out. We picked up:

1 Tonkatsu Sandwich
1 Mabo Tofu Salad
1 Salmon Onigiri
1 Sweet & Spicy Chicken Bento

For me, the Tonkatsu Sandwich was definitely the highlight. The pork was just tender enough to make it easy to eat, but chewy enough to balance the softness of the bread (which came from Acme Bread, also in the Ferry Building). What really stood out was the sweetness of the Tonkatsu sauce. It had just a hint of sourness and really made the sandwich as delicious as I hoped.

The Mabo salad was a very pleasant surprise. I love Mabo Tofu and was unsure of what to expect from the salad. The only way to say it is, it's like mabo in a salad, in a good way. Very tasty.

My friend got the bento and the onigiri. Both were made with very fresh ingredients but I wouldn't argue that they were particularly stand out compared to the other two. The salmon onigiri was very flavorful though.

The ingredients are high quality and they have some definite gems on their menu. However, you really do pay a premium when you eat at the Ferry Building and while most of the time I'd give a place like this four stars because I loved what I had so much, the bento seems to be a bit hit or miss. I recommend going a la carte and finding things you like as opposed to buying a pre-made meal.

Cheers!

excerpts: I really want to try their bento boxes, which are certainly a step up from your average greasy bento box during lunch downtown.
Getting to eat this lunch watching the water from the Ferry Building adds to the charm.
bento.author: Marcel M.
bento.review: This place is delightful. The menu is simple, each dish is made there from scratch, and the ingredients are high quality. Top it off with reasonable prices, and I'm a big fan. So far I've had the salmon chowder (the cup is plenty), the carrot-ginger soup, the crab croquette (amaze!), and the wasabi-potato salad (double amaze!). I really want to try their bento boxes, which are certainly a step up from your average greasy bento box during lunch downtown. Getting to eat this lunch watching the water from the Ferry Building adds to the charm.

excerpts: Beside the awesome Bento box that most people like, I never ordered that here.
I actually just come here for the sushi & the salads.
What I love most is the special daily menu & always fresh surprises.
Today was no different, before my shoot, I decided to swing by to pick up some salumi @ Boccalone,
bento.author: Manda Bear B.
bento.review:
************* REVIEW 99 ****************

Great place to have a light afternoon sushi snack & Japanese food. I come here often when shopping for meat & cheese at the Ferry Building, especially after buy everything I don't need at the Farmer Market.

Beside the awesome Bento box that most people like, I never ordered that here. I actually just come here for the sushi & the salads. What I love most is the special daily menu & always fresh surprises. Today was no different, before my shoot, I decided to swing by to pick up some salumi @ Boccalone,  then I ended up here. 

A few dishes I enjoy very much:

- Seared Toro with Daikon, chai & ponzu sauce - so rich in taste.
- Aji with ginger, chai - I always love this shiny mackerel.
- Hirame carpaccio - 8 pieces thinly sliced with cilantro, olive oil, & sliced of Kumquat - so refreshing & delicate to eat. My FAV dish here!
- Tonkatsu - Pork tenderloin cutlet topped with tonkatsu sauce - giant piece for $1.50 - so crunchy-ly good!

Salads that I like:

- Spicy Burdock Root Salad - very nice, sweet & pleasant.
- Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad -  a spicy kick, rich, & will get you full.
- Tofu, green bean salad - surprisingly nice, great dish for vegetarian!

Service here has always been excellent for me. I love sitting here & looking out the water.  Did I mentioned they serve cold sake in traditional glass & box? nice!

excerpts: They carry everything from a variety of healthy salads - packed with tofu and drizzled with fresh dressings, to chicken katsu, to fresh heavenly smelling curries (both meat and veggie), to take-away sushi boxes, to the most adorable unique bento boxes.
bento.author: Jessica T.
bento.review:
Losing a month long bus pass is painful.

Especially when you lose it at the beginning of the month or half-way into the month.

I have been a victim of these circumstances way too often.

Which speaks highly to the fact that 

1.) I need to get more organized

or

2.) The Universe is telling me to either walk more or contribute more money to MUNI

Anyways, to get to the point -  I lost my bus pass around Delica this past Friday.  Painful, yes. But I was glad to lose it in such a healthy, warm, and uplifting place. The kind woman behind the counter seemed genuinely concerned about my loss, and even tried to get my number incase someone turned it in.

Outside of lost items - Delica is a wonderland of healthy filling and diverse Japanese food items. They carry everything from a variety of healthy salads - packed with tofu and drizzled with fresh dressings, to chicken katsu, to fresh heavenly smelling curries (both meat and veggie), to take-away sushi boxes, to the most adorable unique bento boxes. 

And much more.

If you're able to steal some time away from your office - take the time to visit Delica. They've streamlined their food to make it easy to eat there, or to take your food on the go. The place is well lit, welcoming, and airy, with a considerable amount of seating room - being that it's in the Ferry building.  

Delica isn't exactly cheap - but their food is filling, fresh, and colorful. They take obvious pride in all of their dishes, and the food tastes like it's been concocted and made with love. 

Even though I've lost my magical bus pass for the month of February - I still plan on making many more adventurous trips to Delica before the end of the month.

Trust.

excerpts: However, as I was almost finished consuming the burdock salad that was part of the bento box, I saw a pink painted fingernail.
I was so disgusted to say the least!!
I showed and returned the bento box and asked for a replacement.
The Japanese lady took a picture of the fingernail and said preparers use gloves and that she'll find out whose nail it was.
Really!
She should have returned my money and offer me something else!
She gave me the same salad, but upgraded the sushi to salmon sushi.
She should have pulled out the entire tray of burdock salad from storage!
Not sure if I will order that salad or any greens again!
bento.author: L. M. L.
bento.review: I like this place...sort of fusion Japanese with meticulously prepared sushi, burdock salad, soups, chicken balls, shrimp and crab croquettes, etc. and supposedly, organic greens. However, as I was almost finished consuming the burdock salad that was part of the bento box, I saw a pink painted fingernail. I was so disgusted to say the least!! I showed and returned the bento box and asked for a replacement. The Japanese lady took a picture of the fingernail and said preparers use gloves and that she'll find out whose nail it was. Really! She should have returned my money and offer me something else! She gave me the same salad, but upgraded the sushi to salmon sushi. She should have pulled out the entire tray of burdock salad from storage! Not sure if I will order that salad or any greens again!

excerpts: Workers on their lunch break lined up to grab prepared bento boxes or to make their own combos of 'salads, mains and/or rice.'
bento.author: Fancypants X.
bento.review:
