Despite being a Ferry Plaza dweller, I've never noticed Delica, a bustling Japanese deli, before. Workers on their lunch break lined up to grab prepared bento boxes or to make their own combos of 'salads, mains and/or rice.' Lots of locals--an indication of good eats. 

I ordered white rice, a chicken dumpling ($2) & 3 pieces of spicy chicken ($1.50 each.) While you won't find a wallet-friendly lunch here (my gf spent $20 on a salmon roll & a salad combo), you will find Delica's flavors delicious & interesting. The wasabi potato salad is a spicy twist on the original. The Chinese chicken salad (funny, I thought this was Japanese food!) looked appetizing with its large pieces of veggies & chicken; I'll try that next time. 

Seating inside & in the general area is scarce, especially during the lunch rush, but you'll find plenty of spots to call your own outside with a view of the water to boot.

excerpts: I'm a big fan of the tasty bento boxes with choice of combos.
The downside are the two crazy lines -- one for bento combo boxes (unless you purchase a pre-made bento outside of the shop) -- and the other for single item orders.
bento.author: Diana V.
bento.review:
I'm a big fan of the tasty bento boxes with choice of combos. I like to enjoy them with a friend while sitting at one of the indoor large wooden tables, or more likely, outdoors enjoying the view from the Ferry Building.

Start with the rice, sprinkled with black sesame seeds. Add the Asparagus with Traditional Sesame Dressing (my favorite!!).

Try either the Tofu & Chicken Patty with Hijiki or the Organic Agedashi Tofu Steak.

I never get any of the fried options.

A filling combination if you don't want a heavy lunchtime meal. 

It's a treat for the $10 price tag, but I always find it satisfying.

The downside are the two crazy lines -- one for bento combo boxes (unless you purchase a pre-made bento outside of the shop) -- and the other for single item orders.

I wish they would put up some signage for the uninitiated to ease confusion.

excerpts: I had my first bento box from Delica just a few weeks ago!
bento.author: Abby S.
bento.review:
I had my first bento box from Delica just a few weeks ago! Again, one of those Country Mouse comes to the city stories... 

If you are a soup fan, try the carrot ginger soup from Delica. Nom, nom, nom! With that I had a edamame and seaweed salad and shrimp tempura. All of these were delicious. But it's the carrot ginger soup that really sticks out in my mind.

Can't wait to go back and have some more of that stuff!

excerpts: One to grab the prepared bento to go where as another to select the items you want.
bento.author: Steven M.
bento.review:
I have found my missed Tokyo Japanese cuisine flavor.  I went here during lunch time on a weekday, and there are two lines.  One to grab the prepared bento to go where as another to select the items you want.  I picked the latter and waited quite a while longer.  

I chose the eggplants and pork cutlet.  The eggplants are excellent cold dish item.  It's perfect for warm summer days.  The texture of eggplant is firm without being soggy. The minced meat and sauce on the eggplant makes this an very appetizing lunch item.  The pork cutlet are given in 3 small pieces. They are plenty stomach-fulfilling but the taste is not memorable. All I can remember is the eggplant.

Come down to Delica and enjoy a great tasting Japanese flavor with a front row seat of the bay.

excerpts: Went here for lunch and got the hijiki rice ball and the veggie bento box
so I could try a bunch of different things.
Everything in the bento box was vegan except for the potato croquettes.
The only portion I thought was good was the asparagus salad.
All of the other items - croquettes, hijiki salad, spicy burdock salad, and tofu steak were too bland for me.
Bento box was too pricey at $10.25 for small portions and mediocre tasting food.
Maybe some of their other dishes are better...
bento.author: Kim D.
bento.review: I like that they have many vegan options and everything is clearly marked "vegetarian" or "vegan" on the menu. Went here for lunch and got the hijiki rice ball and the veggie bento box so I could try a bunch of different things. Everything in the bento box was vegan except for the potato croquettes. The only portion I thought was good was the asparagus salad. All of the other items - croquettes, hijiki salad, spicy burdock salad, and tofu steak were too bland for me. Bento box was too pricey at $10.25 for small portions and mediocre tasting food. Maybe some of their other dishes are better...

excerpts: i picked up one of the vegetarian bento box for lunch today and it was delicious!
tofu steak, burdock root salad, and hijiki salad and some steamed rice for $9.75.
yes, that's a litte pricey for lunch box
bento.author: Helen Y.
bento.review:
i picked up one of the vegetarian bento box for lunch today and it was delicious! tofu steak, burdock root salad, and hijiki salad and some steamed rice for $9.75. yes, that's a litte pricey for lunch box but it was healthy and tasty. 


i also enjoyed the chinese chicken side salad.

excerpts: I like sampling their bento, with different and often new dishes to try out.

I tried their hijiki (a kind of seaweed that looks like black grass) which is normally prepared sauteed with fried tofu sacs (abura age) and slivers of carrots (somewhat like this: http://justbento.com/handbook/johbisai/stewed-hijiki-seaweed-carrots-and-fried+tofu).
Theirs included shelled edamame, which would have made me freak, since I mostly eat edamame boiled, salted and with a nice cold Japanese beer.
But they got it right!
bento.author: 和子
bento.review:
I can't always make it to this part of town, but when I do, I always make it a point to stop in, even if I am stuffed to the brim. The food is spot on Japanese with many modern twists. The food is high quality and the flavorings are perfect. It IS set up like a deli or take out joint. I like sampling their bento, with different and often new dishes to try out. I tried their hijiki (a kind of seaweed that looks like black grass) which is normally prepared sauteed with fried tofu sacs (abura age) and slivers of carrots (somewhat like this: http://justbento.com/handbook/johbisai/stewed-hijiki-seaweed-carrots-and-fried+tofu). Theirs included shelled edamame, which would have made me freak, since I mostly eat edamame boiled, salted and with a nice cold Japanese beer. But they got it right! The edamame was not mushy as I would have suspected, and complemented the other ingredients.

I often don't bother getting any sushi from take out joints, because it often sits on ice or refrigeration which just makes the rice stale and hard. However, theirs are freshly made, and, if you time it right, can be quite good. The sushi is generally traditional Japanese style sushi, so if you are looking for the deep fried American style makizushi smothered in hot sauce and mayo, you would be disappointed. In fact, if that is your idea of Japanese food, please skip this place so I can hoard more. Slanted Door on the other side of the building might be more your speed ;)

excerpts: I love their preassembled bento boxes ($9.50 each) - a quick way to grab a healthy, satisfying, portable lunch.
bento.author: Lolia S.
bento.review:
The new menu items caught my eye: ginger pork bowl and okonomiyaki.  They had the actual dishes on display outside the door.  The okonomiyaki was tiny ($5, 2 kinds: vegetarian (mushroom) and chicken), so I ordered the ginger pork bowl ($10).

The ginger pork was cooked to order.  I received four large, thin pieces of boneless, marinated, pan fried pork chops nestled over a bed of steamed white rice, finely shredded raw cabbage and a drizzle of ginger-soy sauce.  The portion was quite generous.  The sauce was too salty and not very gingery.  The pork was quite tough, like my own attempts to cook pork chops at home.  

I'd skip the ginger pork bowl and stick with their croquettes, rice balls, side salads (my favorite is the Hijiki and Soybean Salad but I like all of their salads) and the scrumptious chicken dumplings.  The chicken dumpling isn't just a mushy meatball; water chestnuts add a pleasant crunch, the shitake mushrooms add flavor and texture and the tofu makes it light and tender.  I love their preassembled bento boxes ($9.50 each) - a quick way to grab a healthy, satisfying, portable lunch.  Add on a Japanese bottled drink if you want.

The food isn't a bargain ($2 for one piece of roast beef sushi) but it is fresh, seasonal, high quality and elegantly presented.  You can see that they're busy chopping veggies and cooking in the open kitchen.

excerpts: The bento boxes are to die for.
I've never had anything that I don't like....
bento.author: Jenn R.
bento.review:
I absolutely LOVE LOVE LOVE this place. I used to work in SF, and ate here almost every day. I was so broke. The bento boxes are to die for. I've never had anything that I don't like.... I am not a fan of wasabi, but their wasabi mash potatoes are delicious. 

I also love the assortment of teas. The mango ice tea is my favorite, by far. Green tea is always a classic! 

My only complaint is that this place is expensive! It's soooooo good, that I don't even think about how much I've spent. I'm just glad I don't work in the city anymore.... because EVERYTHING is ooooo soooo delicious.

excerpts: I've seen my coworker come back from Delica with cute and healthy looking bento boxes for lunch
so I finally went and got my own.
I was a little disappointed that my #1 combo (main, salad, salad - had mine with tonkatsu, spinach salad, and hijiki salad)
didn't come with rice.
I'm  not sure if it's supposed to, but it would've gone well with the tonkatsu and accompanying sauce.
The salads were flavorful but light.
However, being veggies, it was only mildly filling, hence the need for some breaded and fried meat.
They put my food in a rectangular white take-out paper box and not a bento box.
Maybe I ordered the wrong thing?
I'd order from Delica again but will pay more attention to the menu next time.
bento.author: Bella L.
bento.review: I've seen my coworker come back from Delica with cute and healthy looking bento boxes for lunch so I finally went and got my own. I was a little disappointed that my #1 combo (main, salad, salad - had mine with tonkatsu, spinach salad, and hijiki salad) didn't come with rice. I'm  not sure if it's supposed to, but it would've gone well with the tonkatsu and accompanying sauce. The salads were flavorful but light. However, being veggies, it was only mildly filling, hence the need for some breaded and fried meat. They put my food in a rectangular white take-out paper box and not a bento box. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing? I'd order from Delica again but will pay more attention to the menu next time.

excerpts: The last time I came here, my bento box was delicious and everything was well-paired.
It's about $10 for a custom-made 4-item bento box, which I think is standard for lunch.
+ It's pretty healthy.
They've got several seaweed, soybean, lotus, vegetably salads that are pretty filling and make you feel good about yourself for eating relatively healthy.
+ I had their chicken dumplings the first time I came, and they were sweet, savory, and a nice way of getting your protein.
- Warning: The 4-item bento box is really just 3 items plus rice.
WHAT!
How deceptive!
bento.author: Vivian C.
bento.review:
What does the name of this place even mean?!  I can understand the Delica part, but rf-1?!  I think it's another case of confused Asian people butchering English grammar, but that's okay.  I think it's amusing.  A friend once told me that in some places in Asia, they purposely hire people with terrible English so that the effect is cutesy.  You know, like when you buy stationary paper that says: "I love heart happy every day we play like me and garden friends ."  If you were ever an Asian girl, you know what I'm talking about.

ANYWAY.

I came here today thinking it would be pretty tasty, but the food was very meh.  The last time I came here, my bento box was delicious and everything was well-paired.  Maybe it was an off day for them today?  

HIT:
+ It's not too expensive, I suppose.  It's about $10 for a custom-made 4-item bento box, which I think is standard for lunch.
+ It's pretty healthy.  They've got several seaweed, soybean, lotus, vegetably salads that are pretty filling and make you feel good about yourself for eating relatively healthy.
+ I had their chicken dumplings the first time I came, and they were sweet, savory, and a nice way of getting your protein.
+  It's in the Ferry Building, always a nice place to take a stroll.

MISS:
- FOOD BLAND. NO TASTE.  DO NOT LIKE.
- The first time I had the potato croquette, it was really tasty.  Today, it was just really meh and cold.  
- Warning: The 4-item bento box is really just 3 items plus rice.  WHAT!  How deceptive!  Rice should NOT be considered an item!  

Final word:  At least the waterfront's nice.

excerpts: Personally, there's bento boxes and a salad side, but I only come here for their curry.
bento.author: Omar L.
bento.review:
I have been coming to Delica for the past 6 years, since I moved to SF.  Although I do not go as much anymore, but I cannot believe that I have not written a review of this place by now.  

Personally, there's bento boxes and a salad side, but I only come here for their curry.  I love the lamb curry when they have it,  but they do not have it all the time.

Expect to wait if you come here around lunch time and find a place to sit sometimes sucks.

excerpts: After both of us hemmed and hawed, we both ordered the $10.95 Bento Box, non-vegetarian division.
There were five compartments of food - some marinated green beans, potato salad topped with edamame, a chicken salad, a rice salad and in the center, some croquette of some sort.
BENTO - 3 stars...
BANZAI!...
BANZAI!...
BAN...!

oh never mind
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...
yes, the Ferry Building rocks...

but it does get crowded
SERVICE - 3 stars...you just pick up and go, grasshopper
TOTAL - 3 star...middling bento for the busy worker bee...with lots of discretionary cash
bento.author: Ed U.
bento.review:
"Please to take off shoes before entering"

...ok, so there's no kimono-clad hostess who tells you that in this rather pricey deli, but hell, I can get away with that 'cause I am Japanese-American, dammit. Honestly, they could use a little more of the homeland ambiance to justify some of their ka-ching, ka-ching pricing.

I never seem to be here when it's open, but I happen to be working nearby now, so I met a friend there for lunch. After both of us hemmed and hawed, we both ordered the $10.95 Bento Box, non-vegetarian division. There were five compartments of food - some marinated green beans, potato salad topped with edamame, a chicken salad, a rice salad and in the center, some croquette of some sort. Can you tell I wasn't too impressed?

Maybe it's because I love the boxes and goodies you can get in the basements of the big Tokyo department stores. And while the packaging may be prettier here, the food is not quite up to snuff. But it's my peeps...so I have to come back and try their sushi rolls or their miso soup sometime, right? They ate moths and roaches on Iwo Jima according to Clint Eastwood, so I could tolerate a non-descript croquette once in a while.

Oh and by the way, good luck finding a seat at lunchtime during the week. And curb your talking trash about your boss, because you just don't know who you're sitting next to now, do you?

BENTO - 3 stars...BANZAI!...BANZAI!...BAN...!...oh never mind
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...yes, the Ferry Building rocks...but it does get crowded
SERVICE - 3 stars...you just pick up and go, grasshopper
TOTAL - 3 star...middling bento for the busy worker bee...with lots of discretionary cash

excerpts: I was told we were having sandwiches for our work lunch meeting so imagine my surprise when the sandwiches turned out to be bento boxes from here!
And not just any bento boxes, but perhaps the best bento box I've ever had!
There were about 9 different foods (fish, veggies, dumplings, etc) in my bento box and I enjoyed every little bite.
Everything was so incredibly fresh and we even got a green tea/mango pudding for dessert-
bento.author: Andrea R.
bento.review:
I was told we were having sandwiches for our work lunch meeting so imagine my surprise when the sandwiches turned out to be bento boxes from here! And not just any bento boxes, but perhaps the best bento box I've ever had!

There were about 9 different foods (fish, veggies, dumplings, etc) in my bento box and I enjoyed every little bite. Everything was so incredibly fresh and we even got a green tea/mango pudding for dessert- it looks gross,but tastes incredible!

My only complaint is that we don't have a Delic rf-1 in Chicago....if we did I would for sure be their best customer!

excerpts: We had the 9 piece bento boxes and they also came with a green tea/mango pudding dessert.
bento.author: Gabi M.
bento.review:
Delica rf-1 catered lunch for a group of around 20 of us earlier this week... it was awesome!  We had the 9 piece bento boxes and they also came with a green tea/mango pudding dessert.

I cleaned my plate (or box in this case).  The fish in the maki was fresh and delicious, and the veggie items were all tasty.  I love different textures in food and so I was pleased with the variety of textures, and the colors too.  Also, I wasn't too full after - it was just the right amount of food so that I was satisfied after but didn't get a food coma.

Can't wait to visit Delica rf-1 in person and try some of the other menu items as well!

excerpts: 'cause I didn't feel like going bento.
Maybe I will try one next time.
The meal was simple and satisfying.
Not heavy at all.
Thumbs up.

Next visit: 
maybe a Bento box 5 items ($9.50), Summer Bento 9 items ($11),
Croquettes, Shrimp Cake ($3.75/ea), Seared Tuna Salad ($10) or Spicy Tuna Genmai Rice Bowl ($10), Hijiki and Soybean Salad or
bento.author: Kay N.
bento.review:
Got Beef Curry ($9.50) and Green Tea ($2) 'cause I didn't feel like going bento. Maybe I will try one next time. 
The meal was simple and satisfying. Not heavy at all. Thumbs up. Will return again.

The Potato ($1.50/ea) and Crab ($3.75/ea) Croquettes looked tempting. 
I think I would feel fairly healthy eating most anything on Delica's menu. 
This restaurant is a good place to bring vegetarian/vegan friends if you want to eat with them near the water. Lots of good options for them. (Notably the Hijiki and Soybean Salad ($15/lb), Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad ($8/lb), Tofu Steak with Miso Sauce ($4/ea), Organic Vegetable Sushi Roll ($7.75/two), and of course the Potato Croquette).

Next visit: 
maybe a Bento box 5 items ($9.50), Summer Bento 9 items ($11), Croquettes, Shrimp Cake ($3.75/ea), Seared Tuna Salad ($10) or Spicy Tuna Genmai Rice Bowl ($10), Hijiki and Soybean Salad or Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad and/or........

Roast Beef Sushi ($2/ea), Sushi Rolls ($7.75/two), Tonkatsu/Pork Cutlet ($1.25), Chicken Dumpling w/Sweet Chili Sauce ($1.75), Kaki-age/Tempura ($3.75).

excerpts: straying from american typical find....sense of "fast food"....already made bento (pre-packaged meals) stacked.....with availability of ala carte behind glass counters.....
preference to build a meal.....
bento.author: Hen A.
bento.review:
mixed feelings for varying selections....dilemma of non-standard....delica rf-1 straying from american typical find....sense of "fast food"....already made bento (pre-packaged meals) stacked.....with availability of ala carte behind glass counters.....preference to build a meal.....balanced selection of tofu, spinach, tofu chicken, spicy chicken, potato croquettes, roast beef sushi and rice....adding of green tea bottles from 'frig' and total of $thirty five handed for special two...

quality being fine...but, hindered by pre-made selections....self not accustomed to cold cooked.....roast beef sushi interesting and tasteful....wrong to want beef warm?.....cold tofu "steak" with sweet miso onion topping delicious....slight dream of warm fried tofu smothered in hot sauced topper.....tofu chicken patty similar to dumpling filling texture....a frown for cold patty served...spicy chicken hard...potato croquettes room temperature....at last, saved by warm rice...finding baked curry fresh and favorite...rich, hot and delicious....and, great happy hour 'til seven pm...gave in to $three kirin, $four handroll & thirty% off wine...

excerpts: You're lured in by the chic, utilitarian decor and by the cases of bento boxes, freshly tossed salads, and assortments of sushi, dumplings...
bento.author: Jennie T.
bento.review:
Pure, unadulterated culinary delight. You're lured in by the chic, utilitarian decor and by the cases of bento boxes, freshly tossed salads, and assortments of sushi, dumplings... My mother, brother, and I stood for awhile, wondering what to eat, and a little confounded by the prices.

 2.00 for one dumpling. 2.50 for one beef sushi. 1.75 for a potato croquette. But order we did, and the result was completely worth it. 

The novelty of the food is a lure itself. Everything was refreshingly new to the taste and the senses. The beef sushi is something born out of my bf's own brain, combining his two favorite foods - beef and sushi. The potato croquette was like creamy Thanksgiving mashed potatoes in a fried carapace.. And the chicken dumpling was just amazing. I can't explain what it is, but the fusion of flavors is so memorable. We three ate outside, among the birds and overlooking the ocean.

excerpts: We sampled a bunch of their dishes, the summer bento, various salads etc.
I thought each was tasty, but these dishes are the real deal.
Many of the taste combinations and ingredients were unfamiliar, so the meal wasn't as comfy for my stomach as a typical sushi place.
But, definitely worth it for the culinary adventure.
bento.author: Jeremy S.
bento.review: We sampled a bunch of their dishes, the summer bento, various salads etc. I thought each was tasty, but these dishes are the real deal. Many of the taste combinations and ingredients were unfamiliar, so the meal wasn't as comfy for my stomach as a typical sushi place. But, definitely worth it for the culinary adventure.

excerpts: You can either order from behind the counter, or grab one of their to-go sandwiches, sushi rolls, or bento boxes.
bento.author: Ashley M.
bento.review:
This is a great place to either stay and eat, or grab and go! 

Food: They have a range of fresh foods -- sushi, salads, fried goodies, etc.  I always get the spicy tuna roll and the sesame spinach salad.  mmmmm! The spicy tuna is super fresh, they give you lots of tuna, and portion size is good.  The sesame salad is a cold spinach salad, marinated in yummy sesame seeds and a light sauce.  They also have a great tofu salad, wasabi potato salad, and a bunch of other cold dishes to choose from.  I have never got any of the fried choices, but they always look yummy.  You can either order from behind the counter, or grab one of their to-go sandwiches, sushi rolls, or bento boxes.  Very convenient! 

Ambiance/Service: The place is very clean, modern, and arranged in a way that allows the line to flow well.  It is nice that you can see all the food they have to offer through the glass.  I like that they have two separate lines, also: grab and go vs order and go.  The service is always fast and up to par! 

Price: Its a little pricey here for sushi, but hey, its way worth it! I would definitely recommend this place to someone who is looking for somewhere great, yummy, and quick to check out.  

You must check this place out if you are in the Ferry Building (or around the Ferry Building, or no where near the Ferry Building)! :)

excerpts: The Bento Boxes are cute and make for a good snack, cause the portions are really small.
It's a good and bad thing that it doesn't fill you up, but leaves a lot of room to snack on other goodies in the area.
bento.author: S Y.
bento.review:
Not your average deli, it's a Japanese deli. I'm a bit iffy on deli foods that sit in a display fridge all day. But I trust and know the Wasabi Potato Salad here is always served fresh! 

The Kaki-age and Potato Croquettes are awesome, and I don't even use the word "awesome." The Bento Boxes are cute and make for a good snack, cause the portions are really small. It's a good and bad thing that it doesn't fill you up, but leaves a lot of room to snack on other goodies in the area.

excerpts: I am an absolute sucker for Japanese food - not just the sushi sort but the bento box sort too.
the huge refrigerated section filled with all sorts of fun salads and goodies and pre-made, REAL bento boxes.
It was hard for me to choose, but I went with the tonkatsu and eggplant bento box.
And I don't even like eggplant, it just looked that good.
Yes, the eggplant had pork in it
bento.author: Wendy L.
bento.review:
I am an absolute sucker for Japanese food - not just the sushi sort but the bento box sort too.  And Delica has the most beautiful and widest variety of Japanese (lunch) food I've seen in the downtown area.

I've only ever been to the Ferry Buliding on the weekends, and, in the madness I must have overlooked Delica.  When my friend suggested a "Japanese deli" at the Ferry Building, I was sold.  This is my equivalent of a candy store - the huge refrigerated section filled with all sorts of fun salads and goodies and pre-made, REAL bento boxes.  It was hard for me to choose, but I went with the tonkatsu and eggplant bento box.  And I don't even like eggplant, it just looked that good.  Yes, the eggplant had pork in it but if everybody made eggplant like that, I would eat it.

I polished off everything - it was actually a little embarrassing.  And even though I have a big appetite, I had zero hunger pangs all afternoon.  True, the lunch was a bit spendy (just a tad over $10) but worth it.  

The Ferry Building is a "hike" (when I write "hike" I mean a flat, 6-block walk) from my office, but it would be dangerous if it was any closer.

excerpts: I got the bento for 9.95.
This is not typical bento box, more gourmet sauce (katsu with a twist) and unique sushi (seared beef is exceptional).
The box comes with  spinach sesame salad, a main item (tempura and I paid extra for the katsu- unlike any katsu I've tried) and sweet sushi-like rice.
bento.author: Surai J.
bento.review:
This is deserving of best cheap eats in SF!  Located in the trendy and crowded ferry building, it takes a lot to stand out here, being in the same place as the slanted door (SF's most reserved resturant -- and tourist trap :-)  and the farmer's market.

I got the bento for 9.95.  This is not typical bento box, more gourmet sauce (katsu with a twist) and unique sushi (seared beef is exceptional).  The box comes with  spinach sesame salad, a main item (tempura and I paid extra for the katsu- unlike any katsu I've tried) and sweet sushi-like rice.  All of it unique with Delica artistry.  

Fresh, flavorful, different than other bentos.

excerpts: The bento box with chicken katsu.
This is a perfect bento box.
bento.author: Jim B.
bento.review:
I've been going to this place for over two years for lunch. I've never had a bad experience with the food. It's a simple Japanese food to go place, but the food they have is consistently executed flawlessly. They are true professionals.

My favorite dishes:
1. The bento box with chicken katsu. This is a perfect bento box. You get rice, 2 pieces of chicken katsu that's breaded and crispy on the outside and moist on the inside, and two types of salad.

2. Any of the breaded food or tempura dipped food is great

3. The rice and curry dish with a selection of meats.

You can feed yourself for under $10. Great value and great food!

excerpts: We started with a vegetarian bento from the deli (we were able to snag one before Happy Hour started): hijiki, soybean salad, fried tofu, burdock root salad, and a veggie roll.
bento.author: Jennifer B.
bento.review:
I feel like I'm halfway crazy because none of the dishes I recently had at Delica are showing up on their website's menu -- but maybe they have a special Happy Hour menu that's not listed?

We started with a vegetarian bento from the deli (we were able to snag one before Happy Hour started): hijiki, soybean salad, fried tofu, burdock root salad, and a veggie roll. Pretty good, a little pricey ($14). 

At HH, my friend and I each ordered a temaki - tuna and salmon. Pretty standard, but tasted fresh. We ordered some sweet potato fries to start, which came with a tasty dipping sauce. We also shared a baked salmon roll which was incredible, and I swear we got a fried crab roll, too. The drizzled sauce on top tasted like potato salad, but it worked.

The coup de grâce was the yaki curry we ordered when we were too full to finish it. Yaki curry is basically the French Onion Soup of curry bowls, with a bed of rice topped with curry and egg under a layer of ooey, gooey gruyere cheese.

excerpts:
i suppose it would have been easier and cheaper to get a "bento" set but i opted for a la carte:

- Agedashi Tofu ($4.25 per square)
bento.author: Cindy W.
bento.review:
3.5 stars. rounding down because of price. it were only a little cheaper, Delica would easily be a 4 star place.

came early on a saturday so beat the lunch crowd. i was attracted by the beautiful display. i suppose it would have been easier and cheaper to get a "bento" set but i opted for a la carte:

- Agedashi Tofu ($4.25 per square): this was a nice big block of fried tofu with seasonings. i enjoyed it but then i always like agedashi tofu.

- Sweet and Spicy Chicken ($1.25 per piece): they said this was one of the most popular menu items so i decided to get 3 pieces. honestly, it was just ok. and at $1.25 per nugget piece, it's not really worth it.

- Kaki-age ($4 each), which is a mixed tempura, really attracted me for its presentation. It was shaped like a crown, with greens and orange colors from the veggies and carrots. Their versions had shrimp, mixture of shredded vegetables (burdock, carrots, onions, and edamame) and potatoes (I think). Pretty good.

excerpts: I liked the bento boxes and looked good but combinations were not my taste!
I did see that most boxes were gone
so I guess that's good.
As for what I decided was spicy tuna roll pack with huge spicy tuna rolls 5 and do big I could not pick up with chopsticks!!
Also instead of tuna on inside like most sushi the tuna was a ball on top of roll...weird.
And was 9.50 plus tax $10.33..really high priced
but it's SF.
So I decided to make my way to Acme bread...
oh boy
bento.author: Dana D.
bento.review: Okay so heard about this place and decided to walk over and try...I liked the bento boxes and looked good but combinations were not my taste! I did see that most boxes were gone so I guess that's good. As for what I decided was spicy tuna roll pack with huge spicy tuna rolls 5 and do big I could not pick up with chopsticks!! Also instead of tuna on inside like most sushi the tuna was a ball on top of roll...weird. And was 9.50 plus tax $10.33..really high priced but it's SF. So I decided to make my way to Acme bread...oh boy

excerpts: Grab a bento lunch and eat it on the deck overlooking the bay.
bento.author: Rick K.
bento.review: Delica is authentic Japanese food.  Lots of great, healthy items on the menu.  I'd give it five stars, but today my lunch was a bit off.  There were too many good things on the menu and I couldn't decide, but ultimately my selection was not good.  My SO had already selected what I wanted (the eggplant salad), so I went with the green beans, tofu steak and rice.  I guess my disappointment was that I expected the rice and tofu to be warm, but both were cold.  Nevertheless the eggplant and pork cutlet (tonkatsu) that the others ordered were much better.  So thus the 4 stars.  But i still like this place because the food is authentic Japanese, fresh, and healthy.  And the location is prime.  Grab a bento lunch and eat it on the deck overlooking the bay.

excerpts: You can skip the long-ass line, and just grab one of the bento boxes...you will not be disappointed.
I'm particularly digging the shrimp cakes!
bento.author: Holly R.
bento.review: One of my favorite spots for a quick lunch during the workday. You can skip the long-ass line, and just grab one of the bento boxes...you will not be disappointed. I'm particularly digging the shrimp cakes!

excerpts: I opted for the bento box filled with spicy chicken, lotus root salad and asparagus salad with sesame dressing.
Some may say that a $10 bento is a bit pricey but you get what you pay for.
The food is fresh, delicious and healthy.
The quality of the the ingredients speak for itself.
bento.author: Lis A.
bento.review:
A Japanese deli called DeliCA?  What a strange concept!  

I was intrigued because being a New Yorker at heart I think of Katz's or Carnegie Delicatessen with pastrami sandwiches when people say deli.  I was pleasantly surprised when I tried DeliCA.

Basically the whole premise behind DeliCA is a top-notch selection of specialty Japanese dishes made from fresh local ingredients, that you can pick from to create a combo meal.  I opted for the bento box filled with spicy chicken, lotus root salad and asparagus salad with sesame dressing. 

Some may say that a $10 bento is a bit pricey but you get what you pay for.  The food is fresh, delicious and healthy. The quality of the the ingredients speak for itself.  The asparagus salad and sesame dressing is DELICIOUS!

Healthy, tasty Japanese deli food...perhaps this concept will migrate to the East Coast.

This foodie is a FAN!

Tip:  Try the asparagus salad with sesame dressing.

excerpts: Their bento boxes are near perfection.
Highly recommended.
bento.author: Daniel H.
bento.review: These guys are pretty much my go to spot everyday Saturday afternoon after working out at the Y. Their bento boxes are near perfection. Highly recommended.

excerpts: I enjoy the bento boxes because you get to sample a lot of different foods.
The salads are inventive, fresh and always delicious!
bento.author: Susan B.
bento.review: I like that they have Japanese food that's not teriyaki nor california roll.Who knows if they really have wasabi potato salad in Japan, but it's good stuff. I enjoy the bento boxes because you get to sample a lot of different foods. The salads are inventive, fresh and always delicious!

excerpts: I got the seasonal veggie bento box and the variety of vegetables, not to mention the creative and yummy preparation simply blew me away.
Despite $10 for a bento box it was very filling as well.
bento.author: Jean K.
bento.review:
This place rocks!  If all vegetables were prepared this well and this tasty I would seriously consider becoming vegetarian.  I got the seasonal veggie bento box and the variety of vegetables, not to mention the creative and yummy preparation simply blew me away.  I like my vegetables fresh and tasting like vegetables (because I do have tastebuds and can appreciate subtle flavors instead of drowning everything in salt) and this place hits all the right spots.

Despite $10 for a bento box it was very filling as well.

excerpts: I want to go back and try the bento boxes, but I am a bit concerned the line.
There are two lines in the place which makes serving very efficient.
The bento box line is always significantly longer than  the salad/sushi line.
bento.author: Katharine A.
bento.review:
After several co-workers recommended this place I had to try it.   I think this place is great for people who work in the FiDi for lunch, or for people looking to lunch outside on a beautiful SF day.  The atmosphere is not much (albeit stark and clean), but the food is amazing. 

This place is truly a little piece of heaven.   Fresh ingredients prepared well.  

I had two salads (Chinese chicken and asparagus) and a main (roast beef sushi--phenomenal!).  I thought that t was possible that this wouldn't be enough food at first, but I was stuffed at the end. 

All items are put in a compact box. I LOVED the fact that the person who composed my meal separated each piece so that all the flavors did not mesh together. 

I want to go back and try the bento boxes, but I am a bit concerned the line.  There are two lines in the place which makes serving very efficient.  The bento box line is always significantly longer than  the salad/sushi line. 

My only complaint: 
The sesame spinach was NOT good. It was very bland and flavorless.   I will skip it next time.

This place has a lot of veggie and vegan options, so it is good for all diets.  

I found this place to be a relative good deal as compared with other lunch choices in the FiDi and Ferry Building.

excerpts: I ended up buying a bento box with rice, tonkatsu, and the wasabi potato salad.
The tonkatsu was perfectly crispy and the tangy sauce was the perfect accoutrement.
Though it was a fried item, the tonkatsu tasted very light- probably a result of Delica's fresh ingredients.
I was a little more iffy on the wasabi potato salad.
I thoroughly enjoyed the crispness of the potatoes, but the combination of romaine lettuce leaves with the potatoes was a little weird for me texture wise.
Overall, a great lunch, even though it was on the pricey side (~$10).
bento.author: Angela L.
bento.review:
I've heard many a rave about Delica from my work colleagues. I finally got something here after we had a pork sandwich adventure fail. 

I ended up buying a bento box with rice, tonkatsu, and the wasabi potato salad. The tonkatsu was perfectly crispy and the tangy sauce was the perfect accoutrement. Though it was a fried item, the tonkatsu tasted very light- probably a result of Delica's fresh ingredients. I was a little more iffy on the wasabi potato salad. I thoroughly enjoyed the crispness of the potatoes, but the combination of romaine lettuce leaves with the potatoes was a little weird for me texture wise. Overall, a great lunch, even though it was on the pricey side (~$10).

excerpts: Anyway, I came here on a Thursday with my managers and we all just grabbed bento boxes and ate.
They had some really good stuff in it.
There was their potato salad type thing with wasabi mayo in it
and I really liked it.
The heat was not unbearable and just enough "BAM" to impress me.
Their food was tasty and original.
I knew this.
bento.author: Wilson K.
bento.review:
Dear Yelp Journal,

You'll be so proud of me.  I actually paid for this meal, all $17 of it.  I know, it's a little bit pricey, but it came from the Ferry building.  I can only imagine what the overhead is like in there.  Regardless, I had a good experience.

I came here with my managers after I had researched a sushi place that was near the embarcadero.  I couldn't find one.  If someone reading this review wants to drop a really good and authentic sushi place near Folsom and Embarcadero to me that would be much appreciated.  Thanks.

Anyway, I came here on a Thursday with my managers and we all just grabbed bento boxes and ate.  They had some really good stuff in it.  There was their potato salad type thing with wasabi mayo in it and I really liked it.  The heat was not unbearable and just enough "BAM" to impress me.  Their food was tasty and original.  I knew this.  It's not what my managers would have liked, which is more traditional Japanese.

Overall, the staff behind the counters were very friendly and the food was good enough for me.  It's a little pricey, but worth it as an occasional eatery.  It's not even expensive enough to justify calling it a splurge.  I would recommend this place, just be careful of the pigeons flying around inside the building.

excerpts: I love bentos, but almost $10 for a simple bento?
That doesn't really fill you up?
Ummmm...expensive.
bento.author: Jocelyn L.
bento.review:
Good food, but Definitely Way Overpriced for what it is

I love bentos, but almost $10 for a simple bento? That doesn't really fill you up? Ummmm...expensive.  Bentos should be around $5-6!

Recently, they renovated and opened an evening tapas + wine bar...the curried potato croquettes were yummy, but waaay salty. The Lotus chips were Great...but $3 for a tiny bowl...

Why can't it be YUMMY And Reasonably-priced?! 
Please???

excerpts: I always go for the bento box that has yet to disappoint.

Here are the bento box options:

4 Items $9.75
bento.author: Carmen Y.
bento.review:
I don't get to eat at Delica's that often as I would like, but everytime that I do, I am quite pleased.

I always go for the bento box that has yet to disappoint.  Here are the bento box options:

4 Items $9.75 
1 Fried + 2 Salads + Rice 

5 Items $9.75 
3 Salads + Half Cut Shrimp Cake + Chicken Dumpling 

9 Items $11.00 
5 Salads + 3 Salmon Roles + Chicken Dumpling

Awesome selections.  Some faves?  Hijiki and soybean salad.  Green bean salad.  Tofu steak.  Chicken dumpling with sweet chili sauce.  Fried shrimp cake.  

Definitely a great lunch spot if you're by the Ferry Building.

excerpts: There are pre-packed bento boxes but also hot dishes plated up as you order them.
bento.author: Yee Gan O.
bento.review:
Delica describes itself as a deli serving prepared Japanese meals to take away but it serves Japanese food I've never seen elsewhere. I'm not sure whether that's because I'm not that familiar with Japanese food or because they've invented some new fusion dishes

Whatever the reason, they have a wonderful way of presenting the food and making it all seem very tempting. The dishes are also well labelled, which is good for some of the less familiar looking dishes.

There are pre-packed bento boxes but also hot dishes plated up as you order them.

I've enjoyed dishes ranging from the roast beef sushi to chicken Okonomi Yaki (griddle cakes) to Japanese curry. All well flavoured and seasoned with some offering a twist on the food found in most Japanese restaurants

Not the cheapest but not terrible for the Ferry Building

excerpts: Items such as chicken dumplings, tonkatsu, tempura, and other fried items as well as ginger kobe beef rice bowls, bento boxes, sushi and salads.
bento.author: Sam L.
bento.review:
I've always avoided this place in the Ferry Building because I once tried a sample of the carrot ginger soup and I almost gagged. I'm no fan of ginger.

So, last week L and I were having a long internal debate on where to eat and chose Delica because it had the shortest line.

The scene:

Much like every other store in the Ferry Building, Delica was fancy. They've got 2 lines out the door - one for salads and one for hot foods. We automatically got into the hot food line not knowing the difference. Each of the food items are on display behind a glass case that stretched throughout the entire restaurant. Items such as chicken dumplings, tonkatsu, tempura, and other fried items as well as ginger kobe beef rice bowls, bento boxes, sushi and salads.

The food:

I totally was not craving anything hot because it was such a beautiful day in the city, but I went for the veggie curry.

Veggie Mushroom Curry - Oh my GOD it was good! It was the best Japanese curry I've ever had. It was very hot, creamy and... crunchy? Yes! The curry was topped with thinly sliced lotus roots that were fried so they have the texture of chips. The two types of mushrooms used in the curry were button and oyter. The taste of the dish as a whole was so unusally satisfying. I've never had any other curry like it. It seriously beats Muracci's and Hotei out of the water.

excerpts: - customize your own bento box (on the left) instead of waiting in the line to the right.
bento.author: T L.
bento.review:
3.5 stars.

TIPS:
- Spicy Chicken is good but they only give you 3 pieces - and they're small!
- tarter sauce is to die for.
- Eggplant Salad (Not always available; seasonal?!) is delicious!
- customize your own bento box (on the left) instead of waiting in the line to the right.

Whenever we walk to the clock tower, we find ourselves here! It's pretty expensive but what looks to be small portions is actually pretty filling.

Always a favorite for a nice, (cheaper) leisurely lunch ... :)

excerpts: I got a Bento box and it was around $10.
You can choose pre packed bentos up front.
I got the one with chicken dumpling (it had sweet sauce on it), rice with sesame seeds, salad and green beans.
The vegetables were good but it didn't seem fresh.
The whole bento box filled me up
bento.author: Jennifer D.
bento.review:
I got a Bento box and it was around $10. You can choose pre packed bentos up front. I got the one with chicken dumpling (it had sweet sauce on it), rice with sesame seeds, salad and green beans. The vegetables were good but it didn't seem fresh. The whole bento box filled me up but I wasn't satisfied.

Too bad I didn't get to taste the roast beef sushi, next time!

excerpts: Tried one of their grab and go bento boxes-
$10, yes it was expensive
but it's hard to spend anything less than that at the Ferry Building
so just suck it up.
I had the sweet n sour chicken bento while my friend had the chicken dumpling.
I really liked the fact that the bento boxes were still warm when i picked it up, so it probably haven't been sitting out for hours.
bento.author: Tenny W.
bento.review:
85 degrees and Sunny in SF?!?!? Definitely the time to grab something from the ferry building and eat on the benches by the water! 

This was the case today. Tried one of their grab and go bento boxes- $10, yes it was expensive but it's hard to spend anything less than that at the Ferry Building so just suck it up. I had the sweet n sour chicken bento while my friend had the chicken dumpling. I really liked the fact that the bento boxes were still warm when i picked it up, so it probably haven't been sitting out for hours. 

I really enjoyed my food, there were 3 huge pieces of chicken (tasty) a good portion of rice and two types of salad. There was just enough of each thing  to keep you full but won't make you feel disgusting afterwards. This place was highly recommended by my friend and she seemed to have enjoyed her lunch as well! The dumplings looked delicious,,, definitely have to try it next time. 

There wasn't a line at all when we went, a little after 12 and it was a great place to pick up freshly prepared for an ok price. Eating lunch out by the water is priceless! Get out of the office and try it sometimes!

excerpts: I've always been a fan of building your own bento box, as well as having the option chosen for me (the pre-made ones are available).
My only gripe with the food here is that if you do get a bento box, it'll be cold.
bento.author: Jeff N.
bento.review:
With a good selection at a reasonable price, there isn't much to fault Delica with.  I've always been a fan of building your own bento box, as well as having the option chosen for me (the pre-made ones are available).  

My only gripe with the food here is that if you do get a bento box, it'll be cold.

excerpts: Prices are a little expensive (around $9-10 for a bento, but you get to mix and match the items that you want, which is nice), but this is kind of expected since it's in the Ferry Building.
I still come here whenever I'm in the area.
Yum!
bento.author: Cassie H.
bento.review:
A Japanese deli lunch place in the Ferry Building.  I really like their various salads, especially the hijiki/tofu salad and the mapo tofu salad.  They taste fresh and have nice light flavors.  You can tell the ingredients they use are high quality.  The fried foods are good too. :P  I like the croquettes and the vegetable tempura ball.

Prices are a little expensive (around $9-10 for a bento, but you get to mix and match the items that you want, which is nice), but this is kind of expected since it's in the Ferry Building.  I still come here whenever I'm in the area.  Yum!

excerpts: My latest addiction, love the bento boxes.
bento.author: Sydney L.
bento.review: My latest addiction, love the bento boxes.

excerpts: My bento box contained a very good mushroom salad, fishy seaweed salad, tasty rice, and three small pieces of sweet & sour deep fried chicken.

If I could do it over again (and if we're getting re-dos in general, I'd liked to have not hooked up with Minnie Driver's opening act that one time - you know, the Carrot Top body double who made me rock-paper-scissors for the check?)
I would order the mushroom salad, chinese chicken salad, rice, and umm...
bento.author: Janney B.
bento.review:
Today, huddled around a freezing cold table behind the Ferry Building, three lunch buddies made their 2009 New Year's Resolutions.  

Among these resolutions were vows to payoff bills, compete in a triathalon, exercise regularly, and get a sole-proprietorship off the ground.  (Okay, so those were my friends' goals.  Mine were a little more shallow and of the "drop 25 pounds and don't be a slut" variety).

Our lunch at Delica RF-1 was okay and close to what I had expected.  I never know what to order here, because there are so many options and the line confuses me (go to the right, now go to the left, now stand in the center).  I used to get beat-up as a kid because I sucked at Simon Says and today I half expected to turn around and see Trailer Park Rhonda ready to pummel me with mismatched mittens.

My bento box contained a very good mushroom salad, fishy seaweed salad, tasty rice, and three small pieces of sweet & sour deep fried chicken.  If I could do it over again (and if we're getting re-dos in general, I'd liked to have not hooked up with Minnie Driver's opening act that one time - you know, the Carrot Top body double who made me rock-paper-scissors for the check?) I would order the mushroom salad, chinese chicken salad, rice, and umm... well... maybe some more salad.

It was a good thing there's limited seating inside Delica RF-1, because it led to the three of us making some great goals (losers buy shots for the others) and gave me a newfound respect for the seagulls who shivered loudly at our feet.

I didn't finish my lunch today.  Which, coming from a girl whose parents had to lock up junkfood in a safe, says a lot.

Oh, and I sat in seagull sh*t.

At ~$11/person for our small lunches, I doubt we'll come back here to unveil our results at the end of the year.  In fact, if my resolutions come true (they're like wishes, right?), I'll be a 125-pound supermodel with platinum blonde hair and an English accent in no time.  I'll be able to sit in my own sh*t, thankyouverymuch.

excerpts: : 1) Long lines between 11:30-1pm, 2) Over-priced, poorly-selected variety of Bento Box options, 3) $10-per-lunch average.
bento.author: Joseph F.
bento.review:
As my favorite weekday lunch spot near my office, Delica deserves to be my first review on Yelp. Selections are typically moderately-priced, but you definitely pay for quality. I recommend cutting the long noon-time lines by ordering a custom boxed lunch of the Crab Cream Croquette, Chicken Katsu and Chicken Dumpling (with a side of rice, of course). All three are delicious and relatively healthy.

The drawbacks?: 1) Long lines between 11:30-1pm, 2) Over-priced, poorly-selected variety of Bento Box options, 3) $10-per-lunch average.

Regardless, this is still my favorite noon-time spot in SF. 

Oh yeah, and on Mondays theres a pretty hot cashier that works the lunch shift!

excerpts: If you can't decide, get a bento box.
After eating, you won't feel like crap because everything is pretty healthy.
bento.author: Maureen B.
bento.review:
Delica can be very tasty, as long as you don't over do it and have it on an almost daily or weekly basis--as I did this past year. And when you do go, make sure to go by 11:30AM or after 1:00PM to avoid the lunch rush.

Things that you should try are the shrimp cakes, chicken dumplings, tonkatsu, wasabi potato salad, and the black seaweed salad. They also have curries, soba noodle soup, and sushi rolls. If you can't decide, get a bento box. After eating, you won't feel like crap because everything is pretty healthy.

excerpts: The food seems healthier compared to other lunch places and has a pretty good variety: bento box style which included small portions of about five items or order from the counter for one main + two sides for right about $10.
There's s small counter space you can eat at
but since just a few steps outside the door
and you're at the bay, so I've only ever eaten along the water.
Quick service, clean, and helpful staff.
bento.author: Kent W.
bento.review: Like coming to this place for weekday lunch because it's a nice break from the office to take a stroll down to the Ferry Building. The food is different than the "traditional" Japanese style lunch usually offered in the Financial District (i.e. don't expect teriyaki chicken with steamed rice or california roll), which is one aspect I enjoy about this place. The food seems healthier compared to other lunch places and has a pretty good variety: bento box style which included small portions of about five items or order from the counter for one main + two sides for right about $10.  There's s small counter space you can eat at but since just a few steps outside the door and you're at the bay, so I've only ever eaten along the water.  Quick service, clean, and helpful staff.

excerpts: It's almost better to get the packaged combo bento-like meals because you get to try a little bit of everything that way and price is more reasonable.
bento.author: Wendy T.
bento.review: You pick and choose which items you wanna buy (some are a little pricey). Their packaged crab (real crab meat) and shrimp sushi roll was really good.  It's almost better to get the packaged combo bento-like meals because you get to try a little bit of everything that way and price is more reasonable.

excerpts: They have outstanding bento boxes with main choices including tonkatsu, shrimp cakes and chicken dumplings and various side salads (my favorites are the hijiki and soybean salad and the green bean salad).
bento.author: F. P.
bento.review:
If you judge favorites by the number of times you return to a place, then out of all the food choices in the Ferry Building, DeliCA is my clear-cut #1.

They have outstanding bento boxes with main choices including tonkatsu, shrimp cakes and chicken dumplings and various side salads (my favorites are the hijiki and soybean salad and the green bean salad). 

They also have curry options, ginger bowls and interesting sushi roll arrangements.

Avoid going at peak times due to long lines but otherwise, it's a good, quick option for take-out.

It loses a star b/c of the relatively high prices (which is expected being located in the FB, but still ...)

excerpts: I tend to get either the tonkatsu (pork cutlet) or karage (fried chicken) bento, along with the sesame string bean/asparagus and spicy burdock salads.
I'll usually follow that with two pieces of the roast beef sushi.
bento.author: Allen K.
bento.review:
Lately this has been my go-to spot in the Ferry Building.  

This is probably the best fast/casual Japanese lunch spot within walking distance of the Embarcadero.  I tend to get either the tonkatsu (pork cutlet) or karage (fried chicken) bento, along with the sesame string bean/asparagus and spicy burdock salads.  I'll usually follow that with two pieces of the roast beef sushi.  The roast beef here is such tender goodness.

I've also had the curry here on a few occasions, and have loved it as well.

excerpts: My advice is try one of their bento boxes for $9-11 to try a variety of their tasty bits.
bento.author: Liz K.
bento.review:
You know you're infatuated with a place when you start having dreams about the food. My dream was that I was juggling those delicious crab croquettes and chicken dumplings while popping them into my mouth. 

Dr.Melfi: "What is this dream trying to tell you?"

Me: "Well, two things. I either need to make a huge decision and get a job as a juggler or get down to Delica rf-1...and eat chicken dumplings and crab croquettes NOW."

Dr.Melfi: "What kind of work are you in?"

Me: "Waste Management" 

Dr.Melfi: "Do you work for Tony Soprano?"

*silence*

Dr.Melfi: "We'll come back to that."

*silence*

Dr.Melfi: "You mentioned juggling chicken dumplings and crab croquettes."

----------------
This place is one of the many things that I love about the Ferry Building. The flavors of these dishes are a wonderful event of deliciousness on the taste buds.

Lets not forget fresh and healthy.

Few of my favorite dishes (drum roll)
-The Green Beans with Sesame Dressing
-Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad
-Hijiki and Soybean Salad
-Chicken dumplings w/sweet chili sauce
-Crab croquettes 
-Sushi

My advice is try one of their bento boxes for $9-11 to try a variety of their tasty bits.

I have yet to try the curry, so you know I will definitely be back.

My only gripe is that it's a bit pricey. I subtract 0.5 stars for that. But, since it's not an option - LUCKY 5 star review! WooWoo!

Overall: Crowded, but the line moves fast, service is friendly and helpful, one of the best take-outs in FIDI, great food, prices slightly high. Quality rocks over price.

excerpts: The 9 piece Bento Box from Delica is so beautifully prepared, it seemed a crime to actually eat it.
bento.author: Nicole G.
bento.review:
How come nobody ever told me there's a Japanese delicatessen in the city? Wowww, what an amazing concept! The 9 piece Bento Box from Delica is so beautifully prepared, it seemed a crime to actually eat it. I instinctively wanted to frame it when I first saw it. 

For around $10, you get three pieces of sumptuous sushi, hijiki and soybean salad, a chicken dumpling, seaweed salad, and a couple of other special treats. Everything is organic and fresh and even better, wonderfully good for you. 

And...  I hear they have roast beef sushi. What the ??? Not to worry, I have a passion for raw meat.

excerpts:
Super tasty Japanese bento boxes and seaweed salads and tofu goodness.
They surprise with the flavor.  
I think the sushi rolls (wild smoked salmon with cucumber and green onion wrapped with rice paper) and the mixed seaweed/hijiki salad are my favorites.
Just crazy good and a great light lunch.
The prices are a bit high, but the quality is stunningly high for a takeout place.
bento.author: Kev M.
bento.review:
Super tasty Japanese bento boxes and seaweed salads and tofu goodness.
They surprise with the flavor.  
I think the sushi rolls (wild smoked salmon with cucumber and green onion wrapped with rice paper) and the mixed seaweed/hijiki salad are my favorites.
Just crazy good and a great light lunch.
The prices are a bit high, but the quality is stunningly high for a takeout place.

excerpts:
i can't wait to try some a la carte items, but my man and i can't stay away from our faves:

for him: the shrimp croquette bento (comes with asparagus salad, lotus root salad, steamed rice, a couple of large shrimp croquettes and a tasty tartar sauce). 

for moi: the vegetarian bento (potato and soybean salad, lotus root salad, kelp salad with cucumbers, braised tofu with miso/bean sauce)

at $10 per bento, it's pretty much as expensive as dining in a tokyo department store food court.
bento.author: May T.
bento.review:
good god, this place reminds me of tokyo department store food courts. AND IT IS GODDAMN GOOD. i've had their lunch bentos twice and each time, they were just enough in quantity, light and extremely tasty.

i can't wait to try some a la carte items, but my man and i can't stay away from our faves:

for him: the shrimp croquette bento (comes with asparagus salad, lotus root salad, steamed rice, a couple of large shrimp croquettes and a tasty tartar sauce). 

for moi: the vegetarian bento (potato and soybean salad, lotus root salad, kelp salad with cucumbers, braised tofu with miso/bean sauce)

at $10 per bento, it's pretty much as expensive as dining in a tokyo department store food court. 

also, they have bottled apple black tea. i haven't had stuff this good since living in taiwan. 

we take our bentos out to the back, and either sit on a bench or on the ground next to book passage and enjoy the goods with the gorgeous view before us.

excerpts: What a reFRESHing change to have bento boxes delivered from Delica rf-1 for our team lunch!
We each got the 9-item Spring bento box (wasabi mashed potatoes, hijiki salad, seaweed salad, asparagus salad, sushi, dumpling and more) which was extremely light and tasty.
We brought the bento boxes to YBG and had a nice picnic lunch on the grass.
bento.author: Connie C.
bento.review:
I don't know about you, but having deli sandwiches catered to the office is a bit boresville. What a reFRESHing change to have bento boxes delivered from Delica rf-1 for our team lunch!

We each got the 9-item Spring bento box (wasabi mashed potatoes, hijiki salad, seaweed salad, asparagus salad, sushi, dumpling and more) which was extremely light and tasty. We brought the bento boxes to YBG and had a nice picnic lunch on the grass. The mango and avocado dessert was surprisingly yummy!

Forward this to your office manager for the next time your company caters lunch. They offer free delivery to FiDi with orders of $250 or more, otherwise there is a $25 fee for deliveries. It's so much more healthy and exciting than deli sandwiches and chips!

excerpts: The other bento items were not as interesting or unique, but this hijiki salad alone is worth it.
It will be the most expensive "bento" you will ever pay for (3 digits).
bento.author: Ken K.
bento.review:
4 stars for this

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xlXnPitrO9Mjfq3aPAyNVQ?select=HFinPIFit5kSK7PRocOEcA

Hijiki, edamame and what appeared to be natto (without the gooey sticky and stinkiness!) with some fresh mixed greens and a nice light tasty dressing. The other bento items were not as interesting or unique, but this hijiki salad alone is worth it.

If you treat the Ferry Building like a Taiwanese or Asian night market snackapalooza fest, where you basically go from store to store or vendor to vendor to eat something small, if you were to pick only one item from DRF1, make it the Hijiki salad to get your greenz in, then binge all you want on oysters, gelati, caviar, bread, cupcakes, meat, cheese, and whatever is tasty and edible nearby (and don't forget the Hong Kong hot milk tea from Out Tha' Door). 

About a week or two before New Year's, you can pre-order osechi sets here, though it is best to call ahead to reserve and ensure. It will be the most expensive "bento" you will ever pay for (3 digits). But heck, it's New Yearz.

Wikipedia's definition:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osechi

excerpts: The price isn't too bad ($9.75 for one bento box), considering the quality of food as well as prices around this expensive Financial District.
bento.author: Misty C.
bento.review:
Decent lunch joint for enjoying organic Asian (more specifically Japanese) food.  The price isn't too bad ($9.75 for one bento box), considering the quality of food as well as prices around this expensive Financial District.

I haven't tried any single item like Vegetable tempura, Okonomiyaki, or Kara-age, but they all looked very fresh.

Worth a try, if you would like to take a break from work, and have simple yet healthy Japanese lunch.

excerpts: Bento Boxes?
Tasty.
Potato Croquette?
Yummy.
Vegetarian & Vegan options?

Hell yes!
WASABI
POTATO SALAD?!?!
Amazingly good with just the right amount of wasabi not to burn your mouth off, but give it a mouth watering ZING!
love it!
bento.author: Melisser E.
bento.review:
Let me just start by saying, WASABI POTATO SALAD! woo!

Okay, now that that's out of my system.. Delica is a delicious Japanese inspired delicatessen in the Ferry Building. The ingredients are fresh, the decor clean & beautiful, & the prices.. a bit high.
Bento Boxes? Tasty. 
Potato Croquette? Yummy. 
Vegetarian & Vegan options? Hell yes!
WASABI POTATO SALAD?!?! Amazingly good with just the right amount of wasabi not to burn your mouth off, but give it a mouth watering ZING! love it!

excerpts: Those $9, 5-item bento boxes, which look exquisitely dainty, pack a surprising amount of food, from the incredible fried scallops in tartar sauce, to the dumpling of minced pork(?), to the Asian-style potato salad.
And if it's still not enough, you could toss in one of those fist-sized shrimp tempura clusters for $3.75.
All told, Delica Rf1 may be the best way to taste the legendary Ferry Building innovation without the bitter aftertaste of an empty wallet.
One suggestion: how about doing the earth a favor and serving the food in wooden bento boxes that you return when you're done?
Just put one of those radio tags on them like they do at clothing stores...
bento.author: Wes M.
bento.review:
Japanese food in the Ferry Building?  Thiiiis is gonna cost me.

Or is it?  Those $9, 5-item bento boxes, which look exquisitely dainty, pack a surprising amount of food, from the incredible fried scallops in tartar sauce, to the dumpling of minced pork(?), to the Asian-style potato salad.  And if it's still not enough, you could toss in one of those fist-sized shrimp tempura clusters for $3.75.  All told, Delica Rf1 may be the best way to taste the legendary Ferry Building innovation without the bitter aftertaste of an empty wallet.  There's even enough variety to keep things interesting for multiple return visits, which is more than I can say for Mijita.

One suggestion: how about doing the earth a favor and serving the food in wooden bento boxes that you return when you're done?  Just put one of those radio tags on them like they do at clothing stores...

excerpts: Their bento boxes are so so good too, especially the Asparagus one.
bento.author: D S.
bento.review:
This place is so amazing, it makes the trip from LA to SF complete for me.

Got the Ginger Kobe Beef & Scrambled Egg Bowl ($8.75) and it was delicious! Very filling meal that I shared w/ my bf. Their bento boxes are so so good too, especially the Asparagus one.

excerpts: A little confused and disoriented from the cold outside, we moved from the front of the line to the back of the line, then to the Bento Box line and finally to the front of the cashier line.
Where to all of our dismay, we payed a little more than we wanted to.
For a Bento Box and a cup of tap water, I paid $10.
bento.author: Lauren C.
bento.review:
Any guy would have been in heaven to be in my shoes today!  I had the pleasure of having lunch with the two most fabulous girls of Yelp, Janney B. and Anna K.  i know. I know. I'd be jealous of me too!

A little confused and disoriented from the cold outside, we moved from the front of the line to the back of the line, then to the Bento Box line and finally to the front of the cashier line.  Where to all of our dismay, we payed a little more than we wanted to.  For a Bento Box and a cup of tap water, I paid $10.  Luckily for me, it was very tasty and I am definitely full. 

I may have shivered off all of the calories from my meal already since we were forced to sit outside.  Today is not a warm day... at all.
It's FREEZING outside (okay, I'm exaggerating a little, but just a little).

All of the tables inside were full and although I really wanted to cuddle up w/ strangers at the big tables, there was no room.  

Outdoors w/ the seagulls was our destiny. We enjoyed the view of the bay and listened to the seagulls squawk while we discussed our new year's resolutions.  

A common theme was to save $$ and budget more wisely.  With that said, I think we'll be meeting at Subway for their $2.99 turkey sandwich Meal Deal.  Jared would be so proud!

excerpts: A beautiful 4-part bento box with seaweed & soybean salad, mixed marinated root veggies, rice with black sesame and pork cutlet is the special work day lunch that made my day!
bento.author: C L.
bento.review:
Delica is Japanese style with organic, local freshness.

Their menu has a lot of healthy and delicious options, such as organic vegetarian sushi and salmon brown rice balls. 

There are also the less healthy choices that are equally mouth-watering. Their fried pork cutlet is light and crunchy on the outside, tender and juicy on the inside. In fact,  the meat is so soft and tender that I am convinced that it must came from a newborn baby pig! 

A beautiful 4-part bento box with seaweed & soybean salad, mixed marinated root veggies, rice with black sesame and pork cutlet is the special work day lunch that made my day! 

Go for a sweet treat at Miette Cakes afterwards, there is no such thing as a bad day!

excerpts: Bento Box:
2 sides plus the Shrimp Cake.
I highly recommend the Asparagus salad & the Burdock & Lotus Root w/Konnyaku salad.
Asparagus salad is creamy and light, and the Burdock salad is really flavorful and well put together.
The Shrimp Cake is crispy, filled with good amount of shrimp, and not soggy.
bento.author: Laura C.
bento.review:
Love Delica RF.  Couple things I've gotten, which are solid:
Soba Noodle Soup:  ~$9.  Piping hot, with a fried Kariyage (don't think i remembered the name correctly, but basically a giant tempura mixture of veggies & shrimp, typicallly $4 each) boxed separately (i requested it boxed separately so it doesn't soggify in the soup).  The soba noodle is tender and cooked to perfection, and the broth is gery good, not too salty, and not too sweet.
Bento Box:  ~$10.  2 sides plus the Shrimp Cake.  I highly recommend the Asparagus salad & the Burdock & Lotus Root w/Konnyaku salad.  Asparagus salad is creamy and light, and the Burdock salad is really flavorful and well put together.  The Shrimp Cake is crispy, filled with good amount of shrimp, and not soggy.  It is a perfect combination, and great portion.

The only complaint i have (not really a complaint, but i will say it anyway), is that it is a bit pricey.  But then again, everything in the Ferry Building is a bit overpriced.

excerpts: I would be back to try some of their bento boxes as well as their other croquettes and the ahi tuna salad, which looked delicious.
bento.author: Angela H.
bento.review:
I had a hard time deciding between 3 stars and 4- obviously the quality of food here is high, but I wasn't completely blown away by the food I had.  I wanted a light lunch without spending too much money (preferably under $8), but that's just about an impossibility in the Ferry Building.  I had heard about Delica rf-1- kinda hard to forget a name like that so that was my first stop.  I browsed through their selection first before deciding on what I should get- a potato croquette, a piece of tonkatsu, and a roast beef sushi.

The potato croquette and the tonkatsu were very good- the panko breading was very crisp and not oily at all.  They were very good examples of what deep-fried foods should be.  The potato croquette was flavored with caramelized onions, which added sweetness and depth to an otherwise plain piece of mashed potato.  I really wish that I had asked for some ketchup- I think that would have made the croquette tastier.  As for the tonkatsu, the pork was tender and came with a tasty squirt of tonkatsu sauce.  I could have eaten a few more pieces of that with some steamed rice and called it a day.  The roast beef sushi, which was a last-minute addition to my order, was the big disappointment.  While the roast beef was tasty and the sushi rice was all that it should be, I just wasn't wowed by it the way some other Yelpers have been.  

3.5 stars rounded up to 4 because it is one of the less expensive lunches you can get at the Ferry Building and because I was impressed by their deep-fried foods.  I would be back to try some of their bento boxes as well as their other croquettes and the ahi tuna salad, which looked delicious.

excerpts: I got the 5 item custom bento box for $9.50, which included a green bean wasabi salad, a seaweed edamame salad, a renkon salad (I think the english word is lotus root), chinese chicken salad and a chicken dumpling.
Yes, I did make sure to memorize what I got

I give them an extra star for great customer service and alerting me that they can replace the potato salad that normally comes with a bento box for a different salad (because I just don't eat mayonaise... period).
No real ambiance to the place, just a cold sterile steel environment in the ferry building...
but the food is decent and well proportioned...
bento.author: Stephanie H.
bento.review:
Delica rf-1 chronicles Part 6 in the saga "Stephanie Takes Over the Ferry Building, One Bourgeois Boutique at a Time." In Part 5 we had Frog Hollow Farms http://www.yelp.com/biz/frog-hollow-farm-market-san-francisco#hrid:LiiryHj5X_gtPU6w8mMfcQbut now what do we say about Delica?

No line at Delica this afternoon, which was a surprising treat. I got the 5 item custom bento box for $9.50, which included a green bean wasabi salad, a seaweed edamame salad, a renkon salad (I think the english word is lotus root), chinese chicken salad and a chicken dumpling.  Yes, I did make sure to memorize what I got so I could give a thorough play by play.

The renkon salad was the standout of the meal. I could eat a whole meal of just that or the seaweed edamame salad, which mixed subtle flavors, interesting textures, etc. I prefer more cabbage in my chinese chicken salad (this was just a couple pieces of overdone chicken with carrots and celery... which was tasty but not worth it).  The green beans were surprisingly good yet the chicken dumpling was lackluster. Like a little lump of mashed chicken, tofu and water chestnuts with a too sweet sauce on the top. Again, not my favorite.

However, I now know what to order next time--the salads are great. I give them an extra star for great customer service and alerting me that they can replace the potato salad that normally comes with a bento box for a different salad (because I just don't eat mayonaise... period). No real ambiance to the place, just a cold sterile steel environment in the ferry building...but the food is decent and well proportioned...just the right amount but not worth $10 in my opinion. 

I may go back, and I may bump them up a star if their croquette beats my Obachan's... but that is highly doubtful.

excerpts: I love their crab croquette (eat fried food, die young), their precious bento boxes, and that I can easily buy the Japanese style curry (which is neither like Indian curry nor like Thai curry but something made from a large bar resembling large chocolate bars... who knows what's really in it...
it's a little like loving spam...
but hopefully Delica's version is made with other ingredients?).
bento.author: Sooj O.
bento.review:
If only this place was cheaper...but like so many other places in the Ferry Building, the prices are for the tourists and not for the regular office worker.

I love their crab croquette (eat fried food, die young), their precious bento boxes, and that I can easily buy the Japanese style curry (which is neither like Indian curry nor like Thai curry but something made from a large bar resembling large chocolate bars... who knows what's really in it...it's a little like loving spam...but hopefully Delica's version is made with other ingredients?).  I try to stay away from their soba noodles because it always irks me to pay so much for just soba noodles. 

I also adore their signature roll which is some rice rolled around a fried item and then wrapped with rice paper.  Very yummy.  

Great lunch food, bad lunch prices.

excerpts: Their bento boxes are imaginative and the ingredients beautifully prepared.
Yes, it is a bit expensive but the food is wonderful.
They have a potato salad with wasabi in it that is amazingly good and their panko coated fried items still taste light.
Stop complaining about the price, get a nice bento of your choice -
I'm sorry 9 items for $11 is still a good deal - sit by the bay and enjoy the amazing variety of textures and subtle flavors.
bento.author: Jon R.
bento.review:
A Japanese deli - you bet.  Their bento boxes are imaginative and the ingredients beautifully prepared.  Yes, it is a bit expensive but the food is wonderful.  They have a potato salad with wasabi in it that is amazingly good and their panko coated fried items still taste light.  

Stop complaining about the price, get a nice bento of your choice - I'm sorry 9 items for $11 is still a good deal - sit by the bay and enjoy the amazing variety of textures and subtle flavors.

excerpts: You can grab your bento and a bottle of fancy green tea drink, head out the door and enjoy your food on one of the benches overlooking the water and the bay bridge.
Then you deposit all the refuse from your meal in their respective RECYCLING bins.
Unique and healthy food, a beautiful setting, a diverse and progressive city... also included in your lunch - perspective, free of charge.
bento.author: mia s.
bento.review:
Like Japanese tapas in a box.  No need to lunch with a crowd in order to get variety.  You can choose to have tiny portions of up to 9 different items all by yourself.  I love that! 

I usually go for bentos containing my favorites like hijiki salad, the burdock root salad, the goma-ae and the chicken meatball.   When I feel extravagant, I'll get one or more of their fried items like the shrimp cake or the crab cream croquette with my salad items.  For a lighter fare, go for the seared ahi bowl served over spinach and rice.

The food is of high quality and the prices reflect that.  The prices also reflect the amazing location.  You can grab your bento and a bottle of fancy green tea drink, head out the door and enjoy your food on one of the benches overlooking the water and the bay bridge.  Then you deposit all the refuse from your meal in their respective RECYCLING bins.  Unique and healthy food, a beautiful setting, a diverse and progressive city... also included in your lunch - perspective, free of charge.

excerpts: In the end I think we got a bento box, a japanese style curry, with a side of potato croquettes.
We also split a green tea pudding.
Our overall reaction to the food was meh, bland, bland, bland.
I've had better tasting japanese food at the mall.
Maybe we just got there late and we got the rejects no one else wanted.
The only good thing about this meal was the eating the potato croquettes while admiring the sf bay.
bento.author: X marks the spot ..
bento.review: I was taking one of my long walks when I stopped in front of the ferry building late in the afternoon, it wasn't my first time there so I knew there was some grub to be found. This time, me and my walking partner-in-crime wanted to try someplace new. We stopped at delica, and since it was way past lunch, the selection was slim. In the end I think we got a bento box, a japanese style curry, with a side of potato croquettes.We also split a green tea pudding. Our overall reaction to the food was meh, bland, bland, bland. I've had better tasting japanese food at the mall. Maybe we just got there late and we got the rejects no one else wanted.The only good thing about this meal was the eating the potato croquettes while admiring the sf bay.

excerpts: Note: They will sell the fried items by the piece and the salads by weight, but you can also order combo plates and bento boxes with your choice of entree (fried item, tofu steak, etc) and various salads which you can mix and match to your heart's content, great for lunch.
bento.author: Burrito M.
bento.review:
Delica RF-1 is one of my staple favorite restaurants...

All of the fried food choices are fantastic.  They generally fry a batch and then serve from a plate as people order.  If you are lucky enough to get a freshly fried batch, you are in for a treat.
